questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to employee health services 30 minutes after a work-related incident. She works as a phlebotomist and reports that blood splashed into her right eye when she was drawing blood from a 30-year-old male patient. Immediately following the incident, she flushed her eye with water for several minutes. The patient from whom she drew blood was admitted for hemoptysis, weight loss, and night sweats. He is an intravenous drug user and is sexually active with several male and female partners. The phlebotomist has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to drawing her blood for viral serologies, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of raltegravir (or dolutegravir), tenofovir, and emtricitabine is the preferred three-drug regimen for HIV postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) following high-risk occupational exposure. The overall risk of transmission is very low but depends on multiple factors, including the type of exposure, the viral load of the source patient, and, in the case of a needle-stick injury, the type of needle involved. While the HIV status of the source patient is unknown, he has multiple risk factors for HIV infection (IV drug user, sexually active), and PEP should be offered as soon as possible, ideally within a few hours but at least within 72 hours.

Other steps that should be taken immediately after occupational exposure include testing the source person for HCV (HCV Ab or HCV RNA), HBV (HBV surface Ag), and HIV (HIV Ag/Ab or HIV Ab, rapid test preferred). Nucleic acid amplification testing (e.g., viral load testing) should not be performed as an initial screening test for HIV because it has a higher rate of false positives than antibody-based tests, and, furthermore, an undetectable HIV viral load in the source patient or the exposed patient does not rule out HIV transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

Zidovudine was one of the first antiretrovirals used to treat HIV and is still occasionally used to prevent vertical transmission of HIV. Zidovudine is not recommended for the treatment of occupational exposure to bloodborne pathogens.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of tenofovir and emtricitabine is recommended for HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to prevent HIV transmission in patients who are HIV-negative but are at risk of HIV infection (e.g., individuals with a serodiscordant sexual partner or those engaging in high-risk sexual activity). This patient has had a recent occupational exposure, however, meaning a different step is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Providing reassurance would be indicated if there were no true exposure identified, e.g., if the source patient's blood came into contact with skin that was intact or the exposure involved a noninfectious bodily fluid (e.g., feces, saliva, vomit). However, blood coming into contact with the eye is considered a high-risk exposure and this patient is at risk of contracting a bloodborne pathogen; reassurance would be insufficient.

E) INCORRECT:

Sofosbuvir and velpatasvir are used for the treatment of hepatitis C (HCV) infection. Currently, there is no postexposure prophylaxis regimen available for patients at risk of HCV transmission. Recommendations for postexposure HCV testing differ, but treatment is only recommended for documented infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine should be administered in cases of occupational exposure when the HBV vaccination status of the health care worker is incomplete or unknown. This woman's vaccinations are up-to-date and, as a healthcare worker, this would include complete HBV vaccination. No further action is required to prevent hepatitis B infection.
questions.hint: This phlebotomist's mucous membranes were contaminated by blood from a source patient with risk factors for a bloodborne disease.

questions.text: Two hours after admission to the intensive care unit, a 56-year-old man with necrotizing pancreatitis develops profound hypotension. His blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg and he is started on vasopressors. A central venous access line is placed. Which of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of complications from central venous catheter placement?

choices.text: Initiation of periprocedural systemic antibiotic prophylaxis
Replacement of the central venous line every 7-10 days
Preparation of the patient's skin with chlorhexidine and alcohol
Placement of the central venous line in the femoral vein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is not routinely performed after central venous line placement to reduce the risk of catheter-related complications. Flushing of the line with heparin should only be considered in patients who require long-term central venous access.

B) INCORRECT:

Periprocedural systemic antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely performed during CVL insertion to reduce catheter colonization or CLABSI. Flushing of the line with antibiotics is generally only considered in patients who require long-term central venous access or who are immune suppressed.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine replacement of CVL every 7–10 days is not recommended because it does not reduce the risk of CLABSI and unnecessarily exposes the patient to additional procedures. Central lines should be inserted and accessed only when absolutely necessary and then removed as soon as possible. Hospitalized patients with CVLs should be assessed daily to determine whether or not the line can be removed.

D) CORRECT:

Proper hand hygiene and preparing the patient's skin with chlorhexidine and alcohol is the most effective strategy in decreasing the risk of infection (e.g., CLABSI) from CVL placement. Chlorhexidine has proven superior to iodine-based compounds for antisepsis.

E) INCORRECT:

Placing the CVL in the femoral vein would not reduce complications, as femoral lines carry an increased risk of CLABSI due to their location. The preferred sites for CVL insertion are the subclavian and internal jugular veins. While the subclavian site minimizes the risk of infection, it is associated with a higher rate of iatrogenic pneumothorax. The internal jugular site, on the other hand, is associated with a greater risk of infection but a lower risk of pneumothorax.
questions.hint: Precautions must be taken when placing central venous catheters to prevent central-line associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI).

questions.text: A researcher conducts multiple experiments to establish an infection and disease model for Clostridium perfringens in chickens. To ensure that all instruments are free of the pathogenic organism, he uses a disinfectant that oxidizes and denatures proteins. Which of the following disinfectants did the researcher most likely use?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydrogen peroxide is an oxidant that produces hydroxyl free radicals (•OH), which damage essential cell components, including membrane lipids and DNA; however, it does not denature proteins. It is effective against a wide range of microorganisms, including bacteria, fungi, and viruses. In higher concentrations and with longer contact times, it is also sporicidal, but another disinfectant would be much more effective against the highly resistant spores of Clostridium species.

B) CORRECT:

Chlorine-releasing agents (e.g., sodium hypochlorite and chlorine dioxide) act by oxidation and the subsequent denaturation of various intracellular structures (proteins, nucleic acids, cell nuclei). They have both bactericidal and sporicidal properties and are therefore not only effective against most bacteria, viruses, and fungi, but also against the highly resistant spores of Clostridium species.

C) INCORRECT:

Alcohols (e.g., isopropyl alcohol) cause membrane damage and denaturation of proteins, but they are not oxidizing agents. Furthermore, they are effective against bacteria, enveloped viruses, and fungi but not against spores, so they have no effect on the highly resistant spores of Clostridium species.

D) INCORRECT:

Iodine and iodophors (e.g., povidone-iodine) are oxidizing halogen-releasing agents, which penetrate the cell wall and disrupt protein and nucleic acid structure and synthesis. They are effective against bacteria, viruses, and fungi but sporicidal only with a prolonged contact time. Another disinfectant would be much more effective against the highly resistant spores of Clostridium.

E) INCORRECT:

Quaternary ammonium compounds (e.g., benzalkonium chloride) act by inactivation of energy-producing enzymes, denaturation of essential cell proteins, and disruption of the cell membrane. They are effective against bacteria, fungi, and enveloped viruses, but they are not sporicidal and therefore show no effect on the highly resistant spores of Clostridium species.
questions.hint: Clostridium is known to form highly resistant spores.

questions.text: Four days after admission to the hospital for pneumonia, a 68-year-old woman develops abdominal pain and watery, foul-smelling diarrhea. Current medications include intravenous ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin. Stool cultures grow gram-positive, anaerobic rods. She is moved to an isolated hospital room. Sterilization with which of the following agents is most likely to prevent transmission of this pathogen to the next patient who will occupy her room?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chlorine-based solutions (such as bleach) are both bactericidal and sporicidal and can be used to sterilize surfaces and equipment that has been potentially contaminated by Clostridioides difficile. C. difficile spores can remain on dry surfaces for several months and are unaffected by typical sanitary products (e.g., alcohol-based solutions) or normal boiling. The protocol to minimize risk of infection and spread of C. difficile within hospital settings involves isolation of the patient, implementation of contact-precautions, and proper handwashing with soap and water before and after each encounter. Autoclaving is also sporicidal and can be used to sterilize larger equipment that has come in contact with this pathogen.

See “Most common disinfectants and antiseptics” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlorhexidine-based solutions are used as skin antiseptics. They are not sporicidal and, therefore, not effective in preventing the spread of C. difficile.

C) INCORRECT:

Isopropanol-based solutions, such as rubbing alcohol, are not sporicidal and are not adequate for sterilization of objects potentially contaminated by Clostridioides difficile.

D) INCORRECT:

Amine-based solutions (e.g., ammonium) only have a limited bactericidal effect and no sporicidal effect. Use would not effectively prevent the spread of C. difficile infection.
questions.hint: Foul-smelling, watery diarrhea after antibiotic treatment is consistent with colitis caused by Clostridium difficile, which is a gram-positive bacillus that forms spores. The appropriate disinfection method is both bactericidal and sporicidal.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department from his assisted living facility because of fever and cough for 1 week. The cough is productive of thick, mucoid, blood-tinged sputum. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F) and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination shows coarse inspiratory crackles over the right lung field. Sputum cultures grow gram-negative, encapsulated bacilli that are resistant to amoxicillin, ceftriaxone, and aztreonam. Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of this organism to other patients in the hospital?

choices.text: Require all staff and visitors to wear droplet masks
Transfer patient to a positive pressure room
Require autoclave sterilization of all medical instruments
Isolate patient to a single-occupancy room
Transfer patient to a negative pressure room

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions are used for highly contagious diseases that are transmitted through particles of respiratory secretions. These include Neisseria meningitidis, influenza, Bordetella pertussis, and others. ESBL-producing bacteria are not transmitted through droplets and therefore droplet precautions are not indicated in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Positive pressure rooms can be used for immunocompromised patients. They have a ventilation system that creates positive pressure in the room, allowing air to flow out of and preventing air from being drawn into the room. This is not indicated in this patient as he is not immunocompromised, and it would not help reduce transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoclave sterilization of all medical instruments is used in prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, as well as in spore-forming bacteria or fungi. It is not necessary to prevent transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.

D) CORRECT:

Multidrug-resistant strains of bacteria, such as ESBL-producing strains, are a greater public health hazard than infections with organisms of a normal resistance spectrum, and thus need stricter infection control measures. In addition to the standard contact precautions and strict hand hygiene, patients should be isolated in single-occupancy rooms.

E) INCORRECT:

Negative pressure rooms are used for highly contagious airborne diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, measles, varicella, smallpox). They have a ventilation system that creates negative pressure in the room, allowing air to flow into and preventing air from flowing out of the room. Moving the patient to a negative pressure room is not necessary to prevent transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.
questions.hint: Fever, productive cough, and localized crackles are suggestive of pneumonia. The patient's currant jelly sputum, residency in an assisted living facility, alcohol use disorder, and findings of gram-negative, encapsulated bacilli make healthcare-associated Klebsiella pneumonia a likely diagnosis. Sputum cultures show multi-drug resistance, raising suspicion for an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing (ESBL) strain of this bacteria.

questions.text: The surgical equipment used during a craniectomy is sterilized using pressurized steam at 121°C for 15 minutes. Reuse of these instruments can cause transmission of which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Non-enveloped viruses are resistant to dry heat as well as detergent (e.g., quaternary amines) or alcohol-based disinfectants but are typically deactivated by heating with steam (autoclaving).

B) INCORRECT:

Sporulating bacteria, such as Clostridium and Bacillus, are resistant to dry heat, alcohol, chlorhexidine, or quaternary amines. However, spores are typically deactivated by heating with steam (autoclaving).

C) INCORRECT:

Enveloped viruses are readily destroyed by heat and most disinfectants.

D) INCORRECT:

Yeasts (e.g., Candida) can form spores and can, therefore, be resistant to dry heat, alcohol, chlorhexidine, or quaternary amines. However, spores are typically deactivated by heating with steam (autoclaving).

E) CORRECT:

Standard autoclaving, which is typically performed at 121°C for 15 minutes or at 134°C for 3 minutes, is adequate for eradicating most pathogens including spores and non-enveloped viruses but it is often inadequate for eradicating prions, which can cause spongiform encephalopathies (e.g., Creutzfeldt Jakob disease). In order to eradicate prions, instruments used in neurosurgical procedures should be cleaned in strongly alkaline solutions and/or autoclaved for a prolonged duration at higher temperatures.
questions.hint: Autoclaving is a sterilization method that uses high-pressure steam.

questions.text: A study is conducted to determine the most effective ways to prevent transmission of various infective agents. One of the agents studied is a picornavirus that preferentially infects hepatocytes. The investigator determines that inactivating this virus can prevent its spread. Which of the following types of disinfectants is most likely to inactivate this virus?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The disinfecting effect of quaternary ammonium compounds (e.g., benzalkonium chloride) is primarily due to the surfactant action of these compounds on the cell membrane. Quaternary ammonium compounds are typically effective against enveloped viruses but ineffective against nonenveloped viruses.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlorhexidine works by adhering to the negatively charged regions of the cell membrane, increasing membrane permeability, and coagulating cytoplasmic contents. Chlorhexidine has limited activity against enveloped viruses but is typically ineffective against nonenveloped viruses.

C) CORRECT:

Nonenveloped viruses are resistant to disinfectants that primarily work by disrupting lipid membranes. Free chlorine-releasing agents (e.g., sodium hypochlorite, chlorine dioxide) and peroxygen-releasing agents (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) form free radicals, which can oxidize and denature proteins and nucleic acids. These strong oxidizing agents (bleaching agents) are effective against enveloped viruses, large nonenveloped viruses, and small nonenveloped viruses. Aldehydes (e.g., formalin, glutaraldehyde) are also effective against all viruses but their use has been limited in healthcare settings because of their irritating fumes, pungent odor, and toxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

Alcohols (e.g., isopropyl alcohol, ethyl alcohol) cause membrane damage and are effective against enveloped viruses. Ethyl alcohol can also denature proteins and is effective against large nonenveloped viruses such as reoviruses, adenoviruses, and papillomaviruses at concentrations of 60%–80%. However, the protein capsids of certain picornaviruses such as HAV and poliovirus are extremely resistant to denaturation by alcohol. A disinfectant with a stronger protein denaturing effect is required.
questions.hint: Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is the hepatotropic picornavirus. The size of the virus and the presence or absence of a lipid envelope determine whether the virus is susceptible to a particular disinfectant. Picornaviruses, caliciviruses, parvoviruses, and polyomaviruses are small nonenveloped viruses, which have an icosahedral protein capsid that is tough and extremely resistant to many disinfectants.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after stepping on a piece of broken glass. Physical examination shows a 3-cm, ragged laceration on the plantar aspect of the left foot. The physician uses hydrogen peroxide to clean the wound. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this disinfectant?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iodine and iodophors (e.g., povidone-iodine and poloxamer-iodine) act as disinfectants by halogenating RNA, DNA, and proteins of bacteria, viruses, and fungi. This halogenation interferes with their pathogenicity. Hydrogen peroxide is not known to function as a halogenating agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Aldehydes (e.g., formaldehyde or glutaraldehyde) exert an antimicrobial effect by crosslinking proteins and alkylating amino, sulfhydryl, hydroxyl, and/or carboxyl groups. These agents are most often used for surface sterilization (e.g., of clinical instruments); they are not used for decontamination of living tissue because their crosslinking effect is non-specific and tends to exert an unwanted toxic effect on healthy tissues. Hydrogen peroxide is not known to function as a crosslinking agent.

C) CORRECT:

Hydrogen peroxide oxidizes cell membrane lipids, intracellular proteins, and DNA by forming hydroxyl free radicals. It is used in wound disinfection and as a surface disinfectant and is active against bacteria, yeasts, fungi, viruses, and spores.

D) INCORRECT:

Intercalation of DNA is the mechanism of action of bactericidal acridine dyes, which can be used for wound disinfection. DNA intercalation is also the mechanism of action of certain chemotherapeutic agents such as doxorubicin, daunorubicin, and actinomycin D. These drugs fit in the planar surfaces between sequential bases in DNA strands, preventing them from replicating effectively. Hydrogen peroxide is not known to function as an intercalating agent.

E) INCORRECT:

Congealing of the cytoplasm is the ultimate consequence of cytolytic disinfectants such as chlorhexidine. Chlorhexidine is a common antiseptic that functions by disrupting bacterial cell membranes, thereby causing cytoplasmic contents to mix with the cellular surroundings. Once the cytoplasm comes into contact with the negatively charged chlorhexidine molecules, the proteins tend to denature and congeal, rendering them useless for bacterial physiology. Chlorhexidine is effective in pre-operative wound decontamination and could be useful for this patient, but hydrogen peroxide disinfects through a different mechanism of action.
questions.hint: Hydrogen peroxide is an oxidant.

questions.text: Five days after undergoing right hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 62-year-old man has fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and urinary frequency. The surgery was uncomplicated. An indwelling urinary catheter was placed intraoperatively. His temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 118/83 mm Hg. There is tenderness to palpation of the costovertebral angle. The urine collected in the catheter bag appears cloudy. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although it has been shown that urinary antiseptics such as methenamine can have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections, the evidence is limited, and the use of urinary antiseptics is not generally recommended.

B) CORRECT:

The most effective measures for the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (UTIs) are avoidance of unnecessary catheterization, sterile technique during catheter placement, and early removal of urinary catheters when they are no longer indicated; patients undergoing surgery not involving the urinary tract should have their catheters removed as soon as possible (preferably within 24 hours postoperatively).

C) INCORRECT:

Antimicrobial prophylaxis has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Furthermore, excessive use of prophylactic antibiotics should be avoided, because it may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens. Intravenous antimicrobial prophylaxis administered shortly before surgery, on the other hand, is an effective intervention for the prevention of surgical site infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Periurethral care with soap and water is considered adequate maintenance care for an indwelling catheter. However, it has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Likewise, the use of antiseptics for cleaning the meatal area, either before or after catheter placement, has not been shown to prevent infections and may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens.

E) INCORRECT:

Although some recent studies have shown that bladder irrigation with antibiotics, antiseptics, or saline solutions can have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections, this method is generally not recommended because the evidence is limited. Furthermore, antimicrobial bladder irrigation may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens.

F) INCORRECT:

Although there may be a temporary reduction in the number of bacteria found in the urine following the changing of a catheter, daily catheter replacement has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Therefore, indwelling catheters should not be replaced routinely as long as the urinary flow appears adequate.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, abdominal pain, nausea, urinary frequency, flank pain, and cloudy urine suggest pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his 19-year-old cousin, who is the boy's babysitter. The boy fell off his bike on a dirt road and injured his hands and knees during the fall. The babysitter explains she cleaned his wounds thoroughly with a disinfectant spray she found in a first aid kit before bringing him to the office for further medical attention. She does not know whether he received age-appropriate vaccinations. Physical examination shows abrasions on both palms and knees, as well as a 3-cm laceration on the left palm. The cousin is extremely worried she did not do enough to clean the wounds and asks if he is still at risk of infection. The bottle of disinfectant spray the babysitter used contains chlorhexidine. The patient is still at risk for infection with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Clostridium tetani is a ubiquitous gram-positive bacillus and can cause tetanus via wound contamination. Disinfectants such as chlorhexidine, quaternary ammonium compounds, and alcohols are not sporicidal and therefore are not effective at destroying spore-forming bacteria such as Clostridia spp. (e.g., C. tetani, C. difficile, C. botulinum, C. perfringens) and Bacillus spp. (e.g., B. anthracis, B. cereus). Sporicidal agents include halogen-releasing agents (iodine, iodophors, and chlorine-releasing agents), hydrogen peroxide (only at higher concentrations and longer contact times), and aldehydes (e.g., glutaraldehyde). Spore-forming bacteria are also able to withstand high temperatures (e.g., boiling water) and dry environments, but can be killed by exposure to pressurized hot steam (i.e., autoclaving).

B) INCORRECT:

Staphyloccocus aureus, a gram-positive bacterium, is a common pathogen in wound infections but is highly susceptible to chlorhexidine. This patient is not at risk for infection with S. aureus.

C) INCORRECT:

The rabies virus is an enveloped virus transmitted via bites from infected animals (e.g., dogs, monkeys, bats). Chlorhexidine has been shown to have virucidal activity against enveloped viruses, and this patient was not bitten, so he is not at risk for rabies infection

D) INCORRECT:

Pasteurella multocida, a gram-negative bacterium, is transmitted via bites and scratches from cats and dogs. P. multocida is susceptible to chlorhexidine, and this patient's injury is not the result of an animal scratch or bite, so he is not at risk for this infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a gram-negative bacterium, can infect wounds but is susceptible to chlorhexidine. This patient is not at risk for infection with P. aeruginosa.
questions.hint: Although disinfectants such as chlorhexidine are effective bactericidal agents, they do not have proven effectivity against spores.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man who is a prisoner comes to the county jail urgent care clinic because of a 1-month history of productive cough, malaise, and right-sided chest pain. During this time, he also has had shortness of breath and a 6-kg (13-Ib) weight loss. Three weeks ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for pneumonia but his symptoms did not improve. He worked as a construction worker for 15 years. He has HIV infection and hypertension. Medications include lisinopril and antiretroviral therapy. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F) and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. On pulmonary examination, scattered crackles are heard bilaterally; there is dullness to percussion at the right lung base. Chest x-ray shows right-sided hilar lymphadenopathy, a fibrous, cavitary lesion in the right lower lobe, and right-sided pleural effusion. CD4 count is 600 cells/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) can manifest with B symptoms as well as hilar lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion on chest x-ray, all of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, mediastinal masses, which cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough, are a common feature of HL. However, this patient's chest x-ray shows no signs of a mediastinal mass; his cavitary lesion is not consistent with HL. Moreover, patients with HL typically have a dry rather than productive cough and often present with painless lymphadenopathy, especially in the cervical nodes, which is not seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (a: PA view; b: left lateral view) and CT chest (c: with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with nodular sclerosing Hodgkin lymphoma

The PA radiograph shows an abnormal superior mediastinum that is dense, markedly widened, and lobulated (green overlay). On the lateral radiograph, there is opacification of the retrosternal space, which should normally be a clear area. CT confirms the presence of a large anterior locally invasive mediastinal soft tissue mass (arrows).

Li: liver; LV: left ventricle

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary sarcoidosis can manifest with coughing, dyspnea, chest pain, and constitutional symptoms. However, pulmonary sarcoidosis usually manifests with a dry rather than productive cough, and a chest x-ray would show bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and reticular or ground-glass opacities, not a unilateral cavitary lesion.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

The lungs have a pattern of innumerable small nodular opacities. The hila are enlarged and lobulated (red overlay) and the right paratracheal stripe is widened (green overlay).

Bilateral hilar and right mediastinal adenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis and is referred to as the “Garland triad” or “1-2-3 sign.”

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) can manifest subacutely with dyspnea, constitutional symptoms, bilateral crackles on chest auscultation, and pleural effusion, all of which are seen here. In addition, PCP occurs almost exclusively in immunocompromised individuals, such as patients with HIV infection. However, chest x-ray in PCP typically shows symmetrical, diffuse interstitial infiltrates extending from the perihilar region, not a unilateral cavitary lesion. Finally, PCP typically occurs at a CD4 count of < 200/mm3.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pneumocystis pneumonia

Parenchymal opacification is seen in a predominantly perihilar distribution (green overlay)

Pneumocystis pneumonia frequently demonstrates as bilateral perihilar opacification with a fine reticular appearance that progresses to air-space consolidation. On CT, it may appear with a ground-glass appearance. Cystic lesions may also be seen. Atypical findings on imaging include nodules, lymphadenopathy, and effusions.

H: heart; SB: stomach bubble

D) CORRECT:

A productive cough, constitutional symptoms, and chest x-ray findings suggestive of a Ghon complex (hilar lymphadenopathy and a pulmonary lesion) in a patient living in crowded conditions (prison) are strongly suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). The lack of improvement of this patient's respiratory symptoms with antibiotic therapy should further raise suspicion for this condition. Pulmonary TB is often accompanied by tuberculous pleurisy, which manifests with chest pain and pleural effusion, as seen in this patient. The patient's chest x-ray findings are consistent with primary tuberculosis, which commonly affects the middle and lower pulmonary lobes. In contrast to primary TB, reactivation TB most commonly affects the upper pulmonary lobes and manifests with multiple cavitary lesions with calcifications and consolidations.

In patients with HIV, reactivated pulmonary TB can also manifest in the lower lobes. The analysis of sputum specimens via culture, microscopy, and/or PCR is the easiest and least invasive way to confirm suspected active pulmonary TB.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Pleural mesothelioma (the most common type of mesothelioma) can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, constitutional symptoms, and pleural effusion, all of which are seen in this patient. In addition, mesothelioma develops secondary to asbestos exposure, which this patient might have had while working on construction sites. However, chest x-ray in mesothelioma typically shows multiple nodular pleural lesions seen as pleural thickening, not a unilateral cavitary lesion.
Image Description:

CT chest (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with malignant mesothelioma

Nodular pleural thickening (hatched green overlay) encases the left lung and the volume of the left hemithorax (red dashed line) is reduced compared to the right (green dashed line). Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are present (red overlay).

The findings are compatible with malignant mesothelioma, although confluent pleural metastatic disease can have a similar appearance. Both primary and secondary pleural malignancies can cause pleural nodules, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural effusion.

AO: aorta; LV: left ventricle; PA: pulmonary artery
questions.hint: Analysis of the pleural fluid would show lymphocyte-predominant leukocytosis and high levels of protein, lactate dehydrogenase, and adenosine deaminase.

questions.text: The patient is hospitalized. On the ward, a medical student is seen entering the patient's room without taking any infection prevention and control measures. The patient's nurse speaks to her when she exits the room and informs her of the required infection prevention precautions. Which of the following isolation precautions is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the causal organism to other individuals?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions are used to prevent the transmission of pathogens that spread via droplets > 5 μm in size. These measures include the use of surgical masks within a distance of 3–6 feet from the patient. Because tuberculosis is transmitted through even smaller particles that can pass through surgical masks, droplet precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with active tuberculosis (TB) disperse bacilli-containing droplet nuclei (aerosols) while coughing or sneezing, warranting airborne precautions in addition to standard precautions. Patients with suspected or confirmed active TB must be placed in airborne infection isolation rooms (AIIRs) because droplet nuclei can remain suspended in the air and travel long distances. The negative air pressure in AIIRs prevents contaminated air from escaping. Furthermore, patients with active TB must wear surgical face masks in an ambulatory care setting or while being transported to another facility. Health care personnel should wear an N95 respirator (or a higher-level respirator) before entering the AIIR. Airborne precautions for active TB are usually terminated only after the patient has significant clinical improvement, three consecutive negative smears on sputum microscopy (collected 8–24 hours apart), a negative sputum culture, and received treatment for 2–3 weeks.

Other infections requiring airborne precautions include measles, varicella, smallpox, and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) infections (e.g., COVID-19).

C) INCORRECT:

Standard precautions are used for the care of all patients, whether or not an infection is probable. These measures include respiratory hygiene, but not necessarily wearing a mask. Because tuberculosis spreads through small particles that enter the respiratory system with the air, standard precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.

D) INCORRECT:

Contact precautions are used to prevent the transmission of pathogens that spread via direct contact or fomites (e.g., norovirus). These measures include the use of gloves and gowns but not necessarily the use of masks. Because tuberculosis spreads through small particles that enter the respiratory system with the air, contact precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.
questions.hint: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is transmitted via infectious particles measuring 1 to 5 μm.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a fever and rash for 2 days. The rash started on her head and then spread to her chest and arms. She did not receive all of her vaccinations. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 22/min. On examination, there is postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. An image of the rash is shown. The rash fades when the overlying skin is pressed. Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the causal organism to other individuals?

choices.text: Require all staff and visitors to wear a surgical mask within 6 feet of the patient
Require all staff and visitors to wear gloves and a gown before entering the patient's room
Require all staff and visitors to wear an N95 respirator before entering the patient's room
Transfer the patient to a negative pressure room
No further isolation precautions are required

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rubella is a viral infection that is spread by droplet transmission. Therefore, in addition to following standard precautions (e.g., hand disinfection), all staff and visitors who interact with a patient with rubella should adopt droplet precautions, such as wearing a surgical mask when within 6 feet of the patient. The patient should be kept in isolation or patient cohorts (i.e., in a room with those who have the same illness), and a mask should be placed on the patient when the patient is transported out of their room for any reason.

Other diseases that require droplet precautions include Neisseria meningitidis, Bordetella pertussis, Haemophilus influenzae type b, and influenza virus infections. Droplet precautions should be in place until the end of the infectious period; i.e., 7 days after the onset of rash in the case of rubella.

B) INCORRECT:

In this patient with postnatal rubella, the use of gloves and a gown is required as a part of standard precautions (e.g., when performing procedures during which contact with body fluids is anticipated) but contact precautions (e.g., wearing gloves and a gown before entering the patient's room) are not required. Contact precautions are necessary for the care of patients who have diseases spread by contact transmission such as congenital rubella infection and varicella.

C) INCORRECT:

Airborne precautions (e.g., wearing an N95 respirator) are necessary when caring for patients with diseases spread by airborne transmission such as measles and varicella, which commonly occur in patients whose vaccinations are not up-to-date. This patient has rubella, which does not require airborne precautions.

D) INCORRECT:

Airborne precautions (e.g., isolating the patient in a negative pressure room) are necessary when caring for patients with diseases spread by airborne transmission such as measles and varicella, which most commonly occur in individuals whose vaccinations are not up-to-date. This patient has rubella, which does not require airborne precautions.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has rubella, which requires droplet precautions until the end of the infectious period (i.e., 7 days after the onset of rash). Patients with erythema infectiosum, on the other hand, are no longer considered contagious once the exanthem develops and do not require any further isolation precautions.
questions.hint: This patient, whose vaccinations are not up-to-date, presents with low-grade fever, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and a generalized erythematous, blanching, nonconfluent maculopapular rash with medium-sized spots, which are highly suggestive of rubella. The rash of rubella can manifest simultaneously with fever or up to 5 days after fever onset.

questions.text: Three days after admission to the intensive care unit for treatment of major trauma sustained during a motor vehicle accident, a 65-year-old woman develops respiratory distress. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Preadmission medications include candesartan, salmeterol, budesonide, and pravastatin. Upon admission, she was intubated and mechanically ventilated because she was unconscious. Over the past 12 hours, her end-expiratory airway pressure was increased to ensure adequate oxygenation. Her current temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest shows new alveolar infiltrates and air bronchograms in the right lower lobe. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Avoiding overinflation of the endotracheal tube cuff
Starting proton pump inhibitor therapy early

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Routine oropharyngeal and subglottic suctioning prevents the pooling of secretions above the endotracheal tube cuff. Avoiding routine oropharyngeal suctioning would increase rather than decrease the risk of VAP.

B) INCORRECT:

Biofilms of bacteria can adhere to the ventilator circuit and lead to VAP. Therefore, a change in the ventilator circuit is recommended if it is visibly soiled, malfunctioning, or if a new patient is ventilated. However, frequent changes of the ventilator circuit for the same patient increase rather than decrease the risk of VAP because manipulation of the ventilator circuit increases the risk of microaspiration of subglottic secretions.

C) CORRECT:

Sedatives are used in mechanically ventilated patients to relieve discomfort and anxiety and, if a spontaneous ventilatory mode is unavailable, to prevent complications arising from patient-ventilator asynchrony. However, excessive sedation impairs the patient's airway protective reflexes and allows oropharyngeal secretions or gastric reflux to pass beyond the glottis. In intubated patients, these collections can pool in the subglottic region and drain around the endotracheal tube cuff, as microaspirates, into the lower respiratory tract. Using sedation assessment tools and daily titration of the patient's depth of sedation to the minimum necessary level (sedation vacation) can prevent the subglottic pooling of secretions and subsequent VAP. Sedation vacations also prevent VAP by facilitating spontaneous breathing trials and early ventilator weaning.

VAP can also be prevented by measures that decrease oropharyngeal or gastrointestinal bacterial colonization (e.g., oral chlorhexidine rinses, avoiding unnecessary acid suppression therapy), decrease subglottic pooling (e.g., oropharyngeal and subglottic suctioning, semirecumbent positioning of the patient), and decrease the risk of microaspiration (e.g., minimizing patient transport, avoiding frequent ventilator circuit changes for the same patient).

D) INCORRECT:

Adequate inflation of the endotracheal tube cuff (to a pressure of 20–30 mm H2O) is required to minimize the risk of VAP. While avoiding overinflation of the endotracheal tube cuff prevents airway injury (e.g., ischemia, ulceration, and necrosis of the tracheal wall), it does not prevent VAP.

E) INCORRECT:

Acid suppression (e.g., proton pump inhibitor) therapy is used for stress ulcer prophylaxis in critically ill patients with certain risk factors (e.g., traumatic brain injury, prolonged mechanical ventilation and/ or stay in intensive care unit). However, acid suppression also promotes bacterial colonization of the gastrointestinal tract, which increases rather than decreases the risk of VAP.
questions.hint: Tachycardia, tachypnea, fever, and new infiltrates on chest x-ray after being intubated for more than 48 hours indicate ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is most often caused by microaspiration of bacterial flora from the oral cavity or stomach.

questions.text: Four days after an operation for a perforated gastric ulcer, a hospitalized 68-year-old woman develops decreased urinary output, hyperkalemia, and severe uremia. A tunneled central venous catheter is placed in the subclavian vein and renal replacement therapy is initiated. Ten days later, the patient develops fever and hypotension. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 86/50 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The skin overlying the catheter appears well perfused, with no tenderness to palpation and no purulent discharge. Samples for blood culture are drawn simultaneously from the central line and a peripheral vein. Blood cultures from the central line grow nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacilli. Three hours later, blood cultures from the peripheral venipuncture grow the same bacteria. Which of the following is the most effective measure to reduce the incidence of this patient's current infection?

choices.text: Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure in intensive care units
Implementation of real-time feedback loops for hand hygiene compliance
Placement of central venous catheters in the femoral rather than subclavian vein
Administration of ceftazidime through the introducer needle before passing the guide wire
Application of mupirocin ointment to the anterior nares of critically ill patients

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure is an example of an airborne precaution, which is effective in preventing in-hospital airborne transmission of diseases such as tuberculosis, measles, or varicella. P. aeruginosa is spread via contact transmission; standard precautions and contact precautions are effective in preventing nosocomial P. aeruginosa infections but airborne precautions are not. Moreover, in intensive care units, especially ones caring for immunosuppressed patients, a protective environment with a positive rather than negative ambient air pressure is usually maintained (neutropenic precautions).

B) CORRECT:

The most common mechanism for CLABSI is microbial spread (via surface motility and/or biofilm formation) to the CVC exit site from the patient's skin and/or the CVC hub. The hands of health care providers (HCPs) are often colonized by pathogens, resulting in HCPs cross-contaminating patients, other HCPs, and inanimate objects (leading to contact transmission), thereby facilitating nosocomial infections. Strict adherence to hand hygiene measures is necessary to prevent nosocomial infections such as CLABSI. Despite high numbers of hand hygiene stations and visual reminders at hospitals, the level of hand hygiene compliance among HCPs remains low because of lapses (due to work overload), poor situational awareness, and/or intolerance or aversion to certain disinfectants. An effective measure to increase compliance is a real-time feedback loop, in which hand hygiene observers or electronic hand hygiene systems monitor compliance and provide immediate feedback (e.g., verbal feedback on improper technique, data visualization of each hospital floor's hand hygiene process measures). Additional steps to increase hand hygiene compliance include staff training and providing alcohol-based foam rubs (which are quicker to use, more effective, and no more irritating to the skin than soap and water) at hand hygiene stations.

CLABSI bundles (a collection of measures to prevent CLABSI) include proper site identification and technique for CVC insertion (e.g., avoiding the femoral region whenever possible), standardized checklists, and aseptic precautions (e.g., sterile glove use, disinfection with chlorhexidine) for CVC insertion as well as CVC site care, CVC removal as soon as possible, and champions-led rounding. These measures are important adjuncts but not substitutes for hand hygiene.
Image Description:

Use the elbow to dispense disinfectant into the hand, then rub it with the other hand for ∼ 30 seconds. If the hands become dry before this time, dispense more disinfectant.

1. To cover palms, dorsal hands, and web spaces: palm-to-palm and dorsal hands-to-palm, both with fingers together and with fingers interlocked

2. To cover fingers and fingertips: dorsal fingers to opposite palm with fingers interlocked, and rotation of clasped fingers in opposite palm

3. To cover thumbs: rotation of thumb in opposite palm

C) INCORRECT:

When compared with the subclavian vein, placement of CVCs in the femoral vein has a lower risk of certain insertion-related complications (e.g., pneumothorax, hematomas, vein stenosis) but a higher risk of CLABSI. Moreover, femoral CVCs are more likely to result in CLABSIs with gram-negative bacilli and Candida because the groin area has high levels of colonization by these microbes (due to factors such as moisture in intertriginous areas and proximity to the anogenital region) and is harder to keep clean. Femoral CVCs should be avoided.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftazidime is an antibiotic that is effective against P. aeruginosa, and antibiotic lock therapy (e.g., with ceftazidime-heparin solutions) can be used selectively for the secondary prevention of CLABSI (e.g., for patients like this one receiving hemodialysis via tunneled catheters). However, antibiotics are ineffective in the primary prevention of CLABSI and do not have a role before or during CVC insertion (e.g., through the introducer needle). Antibiotics should only be used if indicated and, in such cases, the principle of antibiotic stewardship should be followed.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus, which causes nosocomial infections including CLABSI, often colonizes the anterior nares, and nasal application of mupirocin ointment is recommended for critically ill patients as part of the universal decolonization protocol to prevent methicillin-resistant S. aureus infection. However, S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus whereas this patient has a P. aeruginosa infection. P. aeruginosa rarely colonizes the upper airways (e.g., in patients with cystic fibrosis) and mupirocin is typically ineffective against Pseudomonas spp.
questions.hint: The onset of fever and hemodynamic instability ≥ 48 hours after the insertion of a central venous catheter (CVC) and the growth of the same organism on blood cultures from the CVC and a peripheral vein with a differential time to positivity ≥ 120 minutes indicate a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), even if the CVC's exit site does not show evidence of infection (e.g., tenderness, purulence). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacillus that causes CLABSI.

questions.text: Five days after admission to the hospital for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia, a 76-year-old man develops watery diarrhea and cramping lower abdominal pain. Today, he has had three episodes of foul-smelling, nonbloody diarrhea without nausea or vomiting. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, cefotaxime, and clarithromycin. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Crackles are heard over the right lower lung base. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. Leukocyte count is 13,000/mm3. Stool analysis is pending. In addition to isolating the patient and wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry, which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the organism responsible for this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms?

choices.text: No further infection control measures are required
Wash hands with soap and water

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Health care providers wear an N95 respirator as part of airborne precautions when caring for patients with diseases spread by person-to-person airborne transmission (e.g., tuberculosis, measles, varicella). Prevention of C. difficile transmission does not require airborne precautions.

Legionnaire disease (LD), which causes acute pneumonia and GI symptoms (e.g., watery diarrhea, abdominal pain), can spread in hospitals via airborne transmission as a result of aerosol generation from a contaminated water source (e.g., through an airconditioning unit or shower). However, patients with LD usually develop pneumonia and GI symptoms simultaneously, unlike this patient who developed GI symptoms 5 days after being admitted for pneumonia. Moreover, transmission-based precautions (e.g., airborne precautions) are not indicated when caring for patients with LD because person-to-person transmission of LD is extremely rare.

B) INCORRECT:

Alcohol-based foam or gel hand rubs are quick to use and more effective against most organisms than other hand hygiene methods, but they are ineffective against spore-forming organisms such as C. difficile.

C) INCORRECT:

Health care providers should always follow standard precautions for infection control regardless of whether or not the patient has an infection. Standard precautions are not fulfilled by only isolating the patient and wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry.

D) CORRECT:

Adequate hand hygiene, which is a standard precaution, should always be performed by health care providers (HCPs) for infection control before and after contact with a patient, regardless of whether or not the patient has an infection. In most instances, the use of alcohol-based hand rubs (ABHRs) alone is a quicker and superior method of hand hygiene than washing hands with soap and water. However, hand hygiene with soap and water rather than an ABHR is required if the HCP's hands are visibly soiled or when caring for patients with acute infectious diarrhea or infections due to spore-forming organisms such as C. difficile, because ABHRs are ineffective against spores. Wearing gloves and a gown is an important adjunct in preventing contamination with spores but is not a substitute for hand hygiene. HCPs should wash hands with soap and water before putting on gloves and gowns as well as after removing them.

When caring for patients with contact-transmitted diseases such as C. difficile infection, in addition to standard precautions, HCPs should follow contact precautions (e.g., isolating patients, wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry).

E) INCORRECT:

When caring for patients, health care providers should wear a surgical mask as part of standard precautions when there is a risk of exposure to body fluids or other potentially infectious material (e.g., when performing a procedure that can generate splashes or sprays) and as a part of droplet precautions (e.g., when within 3–6 feet of a patient with a droplet-transmitted infection). Prevention of C. difficile transmission does not require droplet precautions; a different element of standard precautions prevents transmission.
questions.hint: Clostridioides difficile infection, which typically occurs after initiating broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy, is the cause of this patient's gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms (i.e., foul-smelling watery diarrhea, abdominal pain).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man who is a physician assistant at a community clinic comes to the office because he is concerned about having acquired a bloodborne infection. Eight months ago, he sustained a needlestick injury while providing local anesthesia for the incision and drainage of an abscess in a woman with unknown HIV, hepatitis B virus (HBV), and hepatitis C virus (HCV) status. He is vaccinated against HBV and had adequate titers of anti-HBs at the time of the injury. He was prescribed tenofovir, emtricitabine, and dolutegravir immediately after the injury but had to discontinue these medications after 1 week because of nausea and vomiting. The results of the previous HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay performed 4 months ago and the previous anti-HCV antibody titer test performed 2 months ago were negative. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study at this time?

choices.text: Repeat an anti-HCV antibody titer test
Perform an HCV nucleic acid amplification test
No further workup is indicated at this time
Perform an HIV nucleic acid amplification test
Repeat an HIV combination immunoassay test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

After an NSI involving a source patient with an unknown HCV status, the exposed individual should undergo a baseline anti-HCV antibody test followed by an HCV nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) at 3–6 weeks and an anti-HCV antibody test at 4–6 months. This patient had a negative anti-HCV antibody test 6 months after the NSI and requires no further testing for HCV infection.

B) INCORRECT:

After an NSI involving a source patient with an unknown HCV status, the exposed individual should undergo a baseline anti-HCV antibody test followed by an HCV nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) at 3–6 weeks and an anti-HCV antibody test at 4–6 months. HCV NAAT would also be performed for any patient with a positive anti-HCV antibody test in order to confirm HCV infection. This patient had a negative anti-HCV antibody test 6 months after the NSI and requires no further testing for HCV infection.

C) CORRECT:

After an NSI, the exposed individual should undergo a baseline antibody-based HIV test (preferably the HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay) and, if the source patient's HIV status is positive or unknown, follow-up testing at 6 weeks and 4 months (if using the HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay) or at 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months (if using a previous generation antibody-based test). Extended follow-up testing for HIV (e.g., at 1 year after the NSI) is only required if the exposed individual becomes HCV-positive or has impaired humoral immunity because delayed HIV seroconversion can occur in these patients. The decision to initiate postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) against HIV after NSI is made using a shared-decision making strategy based on a risk-benefit analysis (e.g., source patient status, drug toxicities).

Following NSI, provided the source patient has a negative HCV status, no further testing for HCV is required in the exposed individual. If the source patient's HCV status is positive or unknown, the exposed individual should undergo a baseline anti-HCV antibody test and follow-up with an HCV nucleic acid amplification test at 3–6 weeks and an anti-HCV antibody test at 4–6 months. Currently, no PEP against HCV is recommended, but exposed individuals who become HCV-positive should receive direct-acting antiviral therapy.

If the source patient has a negative HBV status or if the exposed individual had adequate anti-HBs titers, no further testing or PEP against HBV is required. If the exposed individual had inadequate titers and the source patient's HBV status is positive or unknown, the exposed individual should receive PEP against HBV with active and passive immunization and undergo follow-up testing with anti-HBc and HBsAg at 6 months.

D) INCORRECT:

A nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for HIV is used as a tiebreaker test in a serial testing strategy (e.g., after a positive HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay but a negative HIV antigen-antibody differentiation assay) in order to diagnose HIV infection. A quantitative NAAT (e.g., real-time polymerase chain reaction), which can measure viral loads, is used to measure response to treatment in patients with confirmed HIV infection and to screen for HIV in children younger than 18 months born to mothers with HIV infection (antibodies can cross the placenta which can cause false positives). With the exception of congenital HIV infection, NAAT is not used as the initial test to diagnose HIV infection or for the follow-up of patients without a confirmed HIV infection because this test has a higher rate of false positives than antibody-based tests and undetectable HIV RNA does not rule out HIV transmission.

E) INCORRECT:

After an NSI, follow-up testing with an HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay beyond 4 months is only required if the exposed individual becomes HCV-positive or has a history suggestive of impaired humoral immunity because delayed HIV seroconversion occurs in these patients. This patient, who is otherwise healthy, had a negative HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay 4 months after the NSI and a negative anti-HCV antibody test 6 months after the NSI; he, therefore, requires no further testing for HIV infection.
questions.hint: If seroconversion occurs following exposure to HIV or HCV, it almost always occurs within the first few months. This principle guides the management after a needle stick injury (NSI).

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-day history of worsening cough, shortness of breath, and fever. The patient lives with his wife, who was diagnosed with COVID-19 1 week ago. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. A chest x-ray shows bilateral reticular opacities. A reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction of a nasopharyngeal specimen is positive for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission?

choices.text: Wearing a surgical mask within 6 feet of the patient
Transferring the patient to a positive pressure room
Wearing gloves and gown even if direct contact with the patient is not expected
Wearing an N95 respirator when entering the patient's room

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions, such as wearing a surgical mask within 6 feet of the patient, are used to help prevent the spread of diseases that are transmitted through large particles of respiratory secretions (e.g., SARS-CoV-2). As SARS-CoV-2 can also be transmitted through smaller, aerosolized particles, surgical masks alone do not provide sufficient protection and do not prevent airborne transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

Hand hygiene is used to help prevent the transmission of infections. Halogen-releasing agents are sporicidal and are mostly used for surface disinfection. To prevent the spread of SARS-CoV-2, alcohol-based hand rubs (for unsoiled hands) or handwashing with soap and water (for soiled hands) are preferred.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive pressure rooms can be used for immunocompromised patients because they help to keep potentially infectious air outside of the room. A ventilation system that creates positive pressure allows air to flow out and prevents contaminated air from entering the room. In order to prevent the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, however, contaminated air should be contained in the patient's room using airborne infection isolation rooms, which provide negative pressure and prevent contaminated air from flowing out.

D) INCORRECT:

Wearing gloves and gown even if direct contact with the patient is not expected is part of contact precautions. While gloves and gown are required standard precautions, direct contact with secretions or fomites is not a major mode of transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and an additional measure is more appropriate for prevention.

E) CORRECT:

COVID-19 is caused by SARS-CoV-2, a virus primarily spread by airborne and droplet transmission. Wearing an N95 respirator when entering a patient's room is part of airborne precautions to prevent transmission. In addition to airborne and standard precautions, which include wearing complete personal protective equipment (i.e., gloves, gown, eye protection), droplet precautions should also be adopted. The patient should be kept in isolation or in patient cohorts and should wear a mask when being transported out of their room.
questions.hint: SARS-CoV-2 is most commonly transmitted by exposure to respiratory fluids.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes presents with features and findings consistent with acute appendicitis. The surgical team plans to take her to the operating room immediately.
Which one of the following interventions is indicated to prevent a surgical-site infection in this patient?

choices.text: Delay showering for at least 48 hours after surgery
Plan to use an alcohol-based antiseptic agent for skin antisepsis at the incision site preoperatively
Initiate an intravenous insulin infusion, with goal glucose values of 80 to 110 mg/dL intraoperatively
Use a razor to remove hair from the surgical site preoperatively
Administer a dose of oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole preoperatively

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

No studies have shown that delaying showering >48 hours after surgery reduces the risk for surgical-site infection.

B) CORRECT:

Surgical-site infections remain one of the most common health care-associated infections. Risk reduction can be accomplished with meticulous operative technique, appropriate skin antisepsis, and the administration of appropriate preoperative prophylactic antibiotics. Preoperative skin antisepsis with an alcohol-containing agent should be used unless there are contraindications. Preoperative hair removal from the surgical site should be done with clippers, not a razor, to minimize skin trauma.

Good preoperative glycemic control has been shown to reduce the risk of surgical-site infections, and data suggest that good glycemic control is also beneficial in the immediate perioperative period. However, this benefit needs to be balanced against the risk of hypoglycemia. Therefore, the American Diabetes Association recommends that the target range for blood glucose levels in the perioperative period should be 100 to 180 mg/dL within 4 hours of the surgery.

The goal of antimicrobial prophylaxis is to reduce the cost and morbidity of potential infection, without significantly increasing the risks for adverse reactions and bacterial resistance. Current guidelines recommend a single preoperative dose of antimicrobial prophylaxis administered within one hour before incision time. Selection of an antimicrobial agent is determined by the class of the wound, the most common bacteria likely to cause the surgical-site infection, and local resistance patterns. Data do not support the prophylactic use of vancomycin routinely during “clean” operations to cover methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. For patients undergoing appendectomy, guidelines recommend a single dose of cefoxitin, cefotetan, or cefazolin, plus metronidazole. Decolonization of known S. aureus carriers using intranasal mupirocin can reduce surgical-site infections.

Key learning point: The risk for surgical-site infections can be reduced using evidence-based practices, including preoperative skin antisepsis with an alcohol-containing antiseptic agent.

C) INCORRECT:

Good preoperative glycemic control has been shown to reduce the risk of surgical-site infections, and data suggest that good glycemic control is also beneficial in the immediate perioperative period. However, this benefit needs to be balanced against the risk of hypoglycemia. Therefore, the American Diabetes Association recommends that the target range for blood glucose levels in the perioperative period should be 100 to 180 mg/dL within 4 hours of the surgery. Aiming for a lower target of 80 to 110 mg/dL would not be appropriate given the risk of hypoglycemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Preoperative hair removal from the surgical site should be done with clippers, not a razor, to minimize skin trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Decolonization of known S. aureus carriers using intranasal mupirocin can reduce surgical-site infections, but oral antibiotic therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole directed against S. aureus does not clearly reduce surgical-site infections.

questions.text:
A healthy 26-year-old medical intern is placing a central venous catheter in a critically ill patient with known HIV/AIDS who is not currently taking antiretrovirals. The intern’s hand slips, and she sustains a needlestick injury from the exposed catheter needle. She has no other recent exposures to HIV. During medical school, she received hepatitis B (HBV) vaccination but did not have testing to confirm seroconversion. She was born in the United States and does not have other risk factors for HBV infection.
Which one of the following combinations of diagnostic tests should this intern undergo immediately?

choices.text: HIV antibody, HIV viral load, hepatitis B surface antibody, and hepatitis C antibody
HIV antibody, HIV viral load, and hepatitis C antibody
HIV antibody, HIV viral load, and hepatitis B surface antibody
HIV antibody and HIV viral load
HIV antibody, hepatitis B surface antibody, and hepatitis C antibody

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure. Testing for hepatitis B virus (HBV) surface antibody and hepatitis C virus (HCV) antibody is also part of the postexposure evaluation to determine immunity to HBV infection and possible infection with HCV before the needlestick exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure. Testing for hepatitis C virus antibody is also part of the postexposure evaluation to determine possible infection with this virus before the needlestick exposure.

C) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure. Testing for hepatitis B virus (HBV) surface antibody is also part of the postexposure evaluation to determine immunity to HBV infection.

D) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure.

E) CORRECT:

When an asymptomatic individual has a needlestick exposure to HIV, an HIV antibody test should be performed right away. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection, and the individual should be referred for evaluation and treatment of HIV infection but not for postexposure prophylaxis (PEP).

Postexposure evaluation should also include tests for hepatitis B virus (HBV) surface antibody and hepatitis C virus (HCV) antibody. A positive test for HCV antibody indicates possible infection with this virus before the needlestick exposure. A positive test for HBV surface antibody indicates that the exposed individual is immune to HBV infection (either from prior vaccination or from seroconversion after prior infection). If HBV surface antibody is negative, another HBV vaccination series should be initiated with PEP.

Baseline complete blood count, liver function tests, and creatinine levels should also be obtained. If abnormal, these values will influence the decision about which combination of antiretrovirals to use as PEP — and will also establish a baseline to monitor for antiretroviral toxicities after PEP initiation.

Key learning point: A person who is exposed to HIV infection from a needlestick injury should undergo an initial postexposure evaluation that includes assessments for prior chronic viral infections (HIV, hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus).

questions.text:
Your gloved hand becomes soiled with feces during evaluation of an 82-year-old woman with dementia and delirium.
Following removal of your gloves, which one of the following hand-hygiene strategies is sufficient?

choices.text: Wipe your hands with disinfecting wipes
No further hand hygiene is required, as long as gloves were used during the entire patient encounter
Wash your hands with soap and water

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcohol-based hand rubs are the first choice for hand hygiene in most situations. However, hand washing with soap and water is recommended when hands are visibly dirty or soiled with blood or other bodily fluids, even if gloves were worn.

B) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence that chlorhexidine-based hand rubs are more effective than hand washing or alcohol-based rubs.

C) INCORRECT:

Disinfecting wipes are not used for disinfecting hands or skin in the hospital setting; they are only appropriate for disinfecting surfaces and may cause irritation if used directly on the skin.

D) INCORRECT:

Some type of hand hygiene should always be performed before and after physical contact with a patient, even if gloves were worn.

E) CORRECT:

The spread of iatrogenic infections can lead to significant morbidity and even mortality in the hospital. Hand hygiene is one of several ways to reduce the risk of contamination. Some type of hand hygiene should always be performed before and after physical contact with a patient, even if gloves were worn.

Alcohol-based hand rubs are the first choice for hand hygiene in most situations. However, hand washing with soap and water is recommended in the following situations:

• After toileting
• When hands are visibly dirty or soiled with blood or other bodily fluids (even if gloves were worn, as in this case)
• During the care of a patient with Clostridioides difficile infection if there is direct contact with feces or if contact with feces is likely
• During C. difficile outbreaks or in settings where there are sustained high rates of C. difficile infection

Key learning point: The most appropriate hand-hygiene technique for clinicians to use if their gloved hands become soiled with feces during a physical examination is to remove their gloves and wash their hands with soap and water.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with end-stage kidney disease requiring hemodialysis is hospitalized after reporting 2 weeks of intermittent fevers and shaking chills that occurred after his dialysis sessions. When he initially presented to the emergency department, he had a temperature of 38.3°C, but the rest of his examination was unremarkable. Two sets of blood cultures were obtained, and he was started empirically on intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin. Within 12 hours, both sets of blood cultures were growing gram-positive cocci in clusters.
On hospital day 2, the patient has an abrupt decline in mental status and requires insertion of an endotracheal tube and mechanical ventilation. CT of the head reveals multiple widely distributed cerebral infarctions. The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit, where a transthoracic echocardiogram reveals a 0.6-cm x 0.5-cm mobile vegetation on his mitral valve.
After 24 hours, the organism recovered from the initial blood cultures is identified as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The patient is continued on vancomycin.
Which one of the following strategies is most appropriate for minimizing the in-hospital spread of this patient’s MRSA infection?

choices.text: Screening cultures and targeted MRSA decolonization of the patient’s health care providers
Addition of rifampin to the patient's current antibiotic regimen to enhance intracellular killing of MRSA
Treatment of all of the patient’s close contacts with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 10 days
No additional interventions beyond the antibiotic therapy the patient is already receiving
Routine hand hygiene with alcohol-based hand rub and initiation of contact precautions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Health care providers may become transiently or permanently colonized with MRSA in the course of caring for patients with MRSA infection. However, the role of routine screening cultures and targeted decolonization of health care providers who care for patients with MRSA has not been definitively established. This approach may be considered as part of an investigation of an outbreak of nosocomial MRSA infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Rifampin is often used as an adjunctive agent in patients with MRSA infections of prosthetic devices or certain deep-seated infections (e.g., central nervous system infections) because of its ability to penetrate biofilms and achieve high intracellular concentrations. Its effect on MRSA colonization and transmission has not been evaluated.

C) INCORRECT:

Household contacts of patients with MRSA infection are more likely to be colonized with MRSA. However, empiric treatment of these contacts with systemic antibiotics (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) should not be part of a strategy to reduce hospital transmission of MRSA. This approach may needlessly expose asymptomatic individuals to the adverse effects of antibiotics and also promote the development of antibiotic-resistant strains of MRSA. Decolonization of close contacts with topical regimens (chlorhexidine solution and mupirocin ointment) may be a reasonable strategy for reducing the risk of recurrent MRSA infections among individual patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Providing appropriate systemic antibiotic therapy to a patient with MRSA infection does not obviate the need for contact precautions, because systemic antibiotic therapy may not necessarily eliminate the risk for MRSA transmission. Moreover, objects in the patient’s environment are often contaminated with MRSA and can be vectors for transmission.

E) CORRECT:

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) causes a wide spectrum of health care-associated and community-acquired infections. Prevention of MRSA infections, including the transmission of MRSA from patient to patient in acute care settings, is a critical component of all infection-control programs.

In 2014, the Society of Healthcare Epidemiology of America (SHEA) and the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) jointly updated the practice guidelines for preventing MRSA transmission and infection in acute care hospitals.
