Among the basic practices recommended for all acute care hospitals is the use of contact precautions for patients with documented MRSA infection or colonization. This recommendation is based on several studies showing that contact precautions can reduce the spread of MRSA, particularly when coupled with active surveillance. Contact precautions include:

• Placing patients with known MRSA infection or colonization in single or private rooms
• Requiring health care personnel to don a gown and gloves upon entering the patient’s room
• Performing routine hand hygiene, preferably with an alcohol-based rub, upon entering and exiting the patient’s room

Key learning point: The most appropriate interventions to prevent the in-hospital spread of a patient’s documented infection with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus are routine hand hygiene with an alcohol-based hand rub and initiation of contact precautions.

questions.text: Five days after admission to the hospital for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia, a 76-year-old man develops watery diarrhea and cramping lower abdominal pain. Today, he has had three episodes of foul-smelling, nonbloody diarrhea without nausea or vomiting. Medications are cefotaxime and clarithromycin. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. Leukocyte count is 13,000/mm3. Stool analysis is pending. In addition to isolating the patient and wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry, which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the organism responsible for this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms?

choices.text: No further infection control measures are required
Wash hands with soap and water

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Health care providers wear an N95 respirator as part of airborne precautions when caring for patients with diseases spread by person-to-person airborne transmission (e.g., tuberculosis, measles, varicella). Prevention of C. difficile transmission does not require airborne precautions.

Legionnaire disease (LD), which causes acute pneumonia and GI symptoms (e.g., watery diarrhea, abdominal pain), can spread in hospitals via airborne transmission as a result of aerosol generation from a contaminated water source (e.g., through an airconditioning unit or shower). However, patients with LD usually develop pneumonia and GI symptoms simultaneously, unlike this patient who developed GI symptoms 5 days after being admitted for pneumonia. Moreover, transmission-based precautions (e.g., airborne precautions) are not indicated when caring for patients with LD because person-to-person transmission of LD is extremely rare.

B) INCORRECT:

Alcohol-based foam or gel hand rubs are quick to use and more effective against most organisms than other hand hygiene methods, but they are ineffective against spore-forming organisms such as C. difficile.

C) INCORRECT:

Health care providers should always follow standard precautions for infection control regardless of whether or not the patient has an infection. Standard precautions are not fulfilled by only isolating the patient and wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry.

D) CORRECT:

Adequate hand hygiene, which is a standard precaution, should always be performed by health care providers (HCPs) for infection control before and after contact with a patient, regardless of whether or not the patient has an infection. In most instances, the use of alcohol-based hand rubs (ABHRs) alone is a quicker and superior method of hand hygiene than washing hands with soap and water. However, hand hygiene with soap and water rather than an ABHR is required if the HCP's hands are visibly soiled or when caring for patients with acute infectious diarrhea or infections due to spore-forming organisms such as C. difficile, because ABHRs are ineffective against spores. Wearing gloves and a gown is an important adjunct in preventing contamination with spores but is not a substitute for hand hygiene. HCPs should wash hands with soap and water before putting on gloves and gowns as well as after removing them.

When caring for patients with contact-transmitted diseases such as C. difficile infection, in addition to standard precautions, HCPs should follow contact precautions (e.g., isolating patients, wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry).

E) INCORRECT:

When caring for patients, health care providers should wear a surgical mask as part of standard precautions when there is a risk of exposure to body fluids or other potentially infectious material (e.g., when performing a procedure that can generate splashes or sprays) and as a part of droplet precautions (e.g., when within 3–6 feet of a patient with a droplet-transmitted infection). Prevention of C. difficile transmission does not require droplet precautions; a different element of standard precautions prevents transmission.
questions.hint: Clostridioides difficile infection, which typically occurs after initiating broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy, is the cause of this patient's gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms (i.e., foul-smelling watery diarrhea, abdominal pain).

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-day history of worsening cough, shortness of breath, and fever. The patient lives with his wife, who was diagnosed with COVID-19 1 week ago. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. A chest x-ray shows bilateral reticular opacities. A reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction of a nasopharyngeal specimen is positive for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission?

choices.text: Wearing a surgical mask within 6 feet of the patient
Transferring the patient to a positive pressure room
Wearing gloves and gown even if direct contact with the patient is not expected
Wearing an N95 respirator when entering the patient's room

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions, such as wearing a surgical mask within 6 feet of the patient, are used to help prevent the spread of diseases that are transmitted through large particles of respiratory secretions (e.g., SARS-CoV-2). As SARS-CoV-2 can also be transmitted through smaller, aerosolized particles, surgical masks alone do not provide sufficient protection and do not prevent airborne transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

Hand hygiene is used to help prevent the transmission of infections. Halogen-releasing agents are sporicidal and are mostly used for surface disinfection. To prevent the spread of SARS-CoV-2, alcohol-based hand rubs (for unsoiled hands) or handwashing with soap and water (for soiled hands) are preferred.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive pressure rooms can be used for immunocompromised patients because they help to keep potentially infectious air outside of the room. A ventilation system that creates positive pressure allows air to flow out and prevents contaminated air from entering the room. In order to prevent the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, however, contaminated air should be contained in the patient's room using airborne infection isolation rooms, which provide negative pressure and prevent contaminated air from flowing out.

D) INCORRECT:

Wearing gloves and gown even if direct contact with the patient is not expected is part of contact precautions. While gloves and gown are required standard precautions, direct contact with secretions or fomites is not a major mode of transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and an additional measure is more appropriate for prevention.

E) CORRECT:

COVID-19 is caused by SARS-CoV-2, a virus primarily spread by airborne and droplet transmission. Wearing an N95 respirator when entering a patient's room is part of airborne precautions to prevent transmission. In addition to airborne and standard precautions, which include wearing complete personal protective equipment (i.e., gloves, gown, eye protection), droplet precautions should also be adopted. The patient should be kept in isolation or in patient cohorts and should wear a mask when being transported out of their room.
questions.hint: SARS-CoV-2 is most commonly transmitted by exposure to respiratory fluids.

questions.text: Three days after admission to the intensive care unit for treatment of major trauma sustained during a motor vehicle accident, a 65-year-old woman develops respiratory distress. Upon admission, she was intubated and mechanically ventilated because she was unconscious. Over the past 12 hours, her end-expiratory airway pressure was increased to ensure adequate oxygenation. Her current temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest shows new alveolar infiltrates and air bronchograms in the right lower lobe. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Avoiding overinflation of the endotracheal tube cuff
Starting proton pump inhibitor therapy early

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Routine oropharyngeal and subglottic suctioning prevents the pooling of secretions above the endotracheal tube cuff. Avoiding routine oropharyngeal suctioning would increase rather than decrease the risk of VAP.

B) INCORRECT:

Biofilms of bacteria can adhere to the ventilator circuit and lead to VAP. Therefore, a change in the ventilator circuit is recommended if it is visibly soiled, malfunctioning, or if a new patient is ventilated. However, frequent changes of the ventilator circuit for the same patient increase rather than decrease the risk of VAP because manipulation of the ventilator circuit increases the risk of microaspiration of subglottic secretions.

C) CORRECT:

Sedatives are used in mechanically ventilated patients to relieve discomfort and anxiety and, if a spontaneous ventilatory mode is unavailable, to prevent complications arising from patient-ventilator asynchrony. However, excessive sedation impairs the patient's airway protective reflexes and allows oropharyngeal secretions or gastric reflux to pass beyond the glottis. In intubated patients, these collections can pool in the subglottic region and drain around the endotracheal tube cuff, as microaspirates, into the lower respiratory tract. Using sedation assessment tools and daily titration of the patient's depth of sedation to the minimum necessary level (sedation vacation) can prevent the subglottic pooling of secretions and subsequent VAP. Sedation vacations also prevent VAP by facilitating spontaneous breathing trials and early ventilator weaning.

VAP can also be prevented by measures that decrease oropharyngeal or gastrointestinal bacterial colonization (e.g., oral chlorhexidine rinses, avoiding unnecessary acid suppression therapy), decrease subglottic pooling (e.g., oropharyngeal and subglottic suctioning, semirecumbent positioning of the patient), and decrease the risk of microaspiration (e.g., minimizing patient transport, avoiding frequent ventilator circuit changes for the same patient).

D) INCORRECT:

Adequate inflation of the endotracheal tube cuff (to a pressure of 20–30 mm H2O) is required to minimize the risk of VAP. While avoiding overinflation of the endotracheal tube cuff prevents airway injury (e.g., ischemia, ulceration, and necrosis of the tracheal wall), it does not prevent VAP.

E) INCORRECT:

Acid suppression (e.g., proton pump inhibitor) therapy is used for stress ulcer prophylaxis in critically ill patients with certain risk factors (e.g., traumatic brain injury, prolonged mechanical ventilation and/ or stay in intensive care unit). However, acid suppression also promotes bacterial colonization of the gastrointestinal tract, which increases rather than decreases the risk of VAP.
questions.hint: Tachycardia, tachypnea, fever, and new infiltrates on chest x-ray after being intubated for more than 48 hours indicate ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is most often caused by microaspiration of bacterial flora from the oral cavity or stomach.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man who is a prisoner comes to the county jail urgent care clinic because of a 1-month history of productive cough, malaise, and right-sided chest pain. During this time, he also has had shortness of breath and a 6-kg (13-Ib) weight loss. He is diagnosed with tuberculosis and hospitalized. On the ward, a student is seen entering the patient's room without taking any infection prevention and control measures. The patient's nurse speaks to her when she exits the room and informs her of the required infection prevention precautions. Which of the following isolation precautions is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the causal organism to other individuals?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Standard precautions are used for the care of all patients, whether or not an infection is probable. These measures include respiratory hygiene, but not necessarily wearing a mask. Because tuberculosis spreads through small particles that enter the respiratory system with the air, standard precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

Contact precautions are used to prevent the transmission of pathogens that spread via direct contact or fomites (e.g., norovirus). These measures include the use of gloves and gowns but not necessarily the use of masks. Because tuberculosis spreads through small particles that enter the respiratory system with the air, contact precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with active tuberculosis (TB) disperse bacilli-containing droplet nuclei (aerosols) while coughing or sneezing, warranting airborne precautions in addition to standard precautions. Patients with suspected or confirmed active TB must be placed in airborne infection isolation rooms (AIIRs) because droplet nuclei can remain suspended in the air and travel long distances. The negative air pressure in AIIRs prevents contaminated air from escaping. Furthermore, patients with active TB must wear surgical face masks in an ambulatory care setting or while being transported to another facility. Health care personnel should wear an N95 respirator (or a higher-level respirator) before entering the AIIR. Airborne precautions for active TB are usually terminated only after the patient has significant clinical improvement, three consecutive negative smears on sputum microscopy (collected 8–24 hours apart), a negative sputum culture, and received treatment for 2–3 weeks.

Other infections requiring airborne precautions include measles, varicella, smallpox, and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) infections (e.g., COVID-19).

D) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions are used to prevent the transmission of pathogens that spread via droplets > 5 μm in size (e.g., influenza) . These measures include the use of surgical masks within a distance of 3–6 feet from the patient. Because tuberculosis is transmitted through even smaller particles that can pass through surgical masks, droplet precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.
questions.hint: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is transmitted via infectious particles measuring 1 to 5 μm.

questions.text: Five days after undergoing right hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 62-year-old man has fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and urinary frequency. The surgery was uncomplicated. An indwelling urinary catheter was placed intraoperatively. His temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 118/83 mm Hg. There is tenderness to palpation of the costovertebral angle. The urine collected in the catheter bag appears cloudy. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although it has been shown that urinary antiseptics such as methenamine can have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections, the evidence is limited, and the use of urinary antiseptics is not generally recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Although there may be a temporary reduction in the number of bacteria found in the urine following the changing of a catheter, daily catheter replacement has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Therefore, indwelling catheters should not be replaced routinely as long as the urinary flow appears adequate.

C) CORRECT:

The most effective measures for the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (UTIs) are avoidance of unnecessary catheterization, sterile technique during catheter placement, and early removal of urinary catheters when they are no longer indicated; patients undergoing surgery not involving the urinary tract should have their catheters removed as soon as possible (preferably within 24 hours postoperatively).

D) INCORRECT:

Periurethral care with soap and water is considered adequate maintenance care for an indwelling catheter. However, it has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Likewise, the use of antiseptics for cleaning the meatal area, either before or after catheter placement, has not been shown to prevent infections and may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens.

E) INCORRECT:

Antimicrobial prophylaxis has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Furthermore, excessive use of prophylactic antibiotics should be avoided, because it may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens. Intravenous antimicrobial prophylaxis administered shortly before surgery, on the other hand, is an effective intervention for the prevention of surgical site infections.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, abdominal pain, nausea, urinary frequency, flank pain, and cloudy urine suggest pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A healthy 26-year-old clinician is placing a central venous catheter in a critically ill patient with known HIV/AIDS who is not currently taking antiretrovirals. The clinician’s hand slips, and she sustains a needlestick injury from the exposed catheter needle. She has no other recent exposures to HIV. She had received hepatitis B (HBV) vaccination but did not have testing to confirm seroconversion. She was born in the United States and does not have other risk factors for HBV infection. Which one of the following combinations of diagnostic tests should this clinician undergo immediately?

choices.text: HIV antibody, HIV viral load, and hepatitis C antibody
HIV antibody and HIV viral load
HIV antibody, HIV viral load, and hepatitis B surface antibody
HIV antibody, hepatitis B surface antibody, and hepatitis C antibody

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure. Testing for hepatitis C virus antibody is also part of the postexposure evaluation to determine possible infection with this virus before the needlestick exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure.

C) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure. Testing for hepatitis B virus (HBV) surface antibody is also part of the postexposure evaluation to determine immunity to HBV infection.

D) CORRECT:

When an asymptomatic individual has a needlestick exposure to HIV, an HIV antibody test should be performed right away. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection, and the individual should be referred for evaluation and treatment of HIV infection but not for postexposure prophylaxis (PEP).

Postexposure evaluation should also include tests for hepatitis B virus (HBV) surface antibody and hepatitis C virus (HCV) antibody. A positive test for HCV antibody indicates possible infection with this virus before the needlestick exposure. A positive test for HBV surface antibody indicates that the exposed individual is immune to HBV infection (either from prior vaccination or from seroconversion after prior infection). If HBV surface antibody is negative, another HBV vaccination series should be initiated with PEP.

Baseline complete blood count, liver function tests, and creatinine levels should also be obtained. If abnormal, these values will influence the decision about which combination of antiretrovirals to use as PEP — and will also establish a baseline to monitor for antiretroviral toxicities after PEP initiation.

Key learning point: A person who is exposed to HIV infection from a needlestick injury should undergo an initial postexposure evaluation that includes assessments for prior chronic viral infections (HIV, hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus).

questions.text: A 70-year-old hospitalized patient with a new MRSA wound infection is cared for by multiple staff members. Which measure best prevents MRSA transmission?

choices.text: Consistent hand hygiene between patient contacts
Daily nasal colonization screening of healthcare workers
Universal contact isolation for all hospitalized patients
Routine prophylactic vancomycin for close contacts

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Proper hand hygiene is essential in preventing MRSA transmission in healthcare settings. Hand washing with soap and water or using alcohol-based hand rubs effectively reduces microbial load on healthcare workers' hands, the primary vehicle for pathogen transmission. Adhering to hand hygiene protocols before and after patient contact interrupts the infection chain, protecting both patients and staff. Guidelines from organizations like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and World Health Organization (WHO) emphasize hand hygiene's critical role in reducing nosocomial infections, especially in environments with multiple patient contacts.

Key learning point: Hand hygiene is the most effective and simplest precaution to prevent the spread of MRSA and other healthcare-associated infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Daily nasal colonization screening of healthcare workers is not effective in preventing MRSA transmission. MRSA primarily spreads via direct contact, particularly through healthcare workers' hands. Consistent hand hygiene and contact precautions are more effective in preventing transmission than routine screening, which does not address the main transmission pathways.

C) INCORRECT:

Universal contact isolation for all patients is not an effective strategy for preventing MRSA transmission. Targeted contact precautions for patients with known MRSA colonization or infection are more effective. Universal isolation can strain resources and divert attention from critical practices like hand hygiene and environmental cleaning.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine prophylactic vancomycin for close contacts is not effective in preventing MRSA transmission. The primary transmission route is direct contact, particularly through healthcare workers' hands. Prophylactic antibiotics do not address environmental and procedural factors and may lead to adverse effects and antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: Four neonates in a nursery develop new hospital-acquired infections despite thorough surface disinfection. Which intervention is most effective at preventing further transmission?

choices.text: Strict hand hygiene before and after patient contact

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Strict hand hygiene is crucial in preventing hospital-acquired infections, especially in neonatal nurseries where infants have immature immune systems. Healthcare workers' hands are common vectors for pathogen transmission. Cleansing hands before and after patient contact disrupts the infection chain by removing transient microbes. Guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention emphasize hand hygiene as a key measure in reducing hospital-acquired infections.

Key learning point: Thorough hand washing is the most effective measure to prevent infection transmission in healthcare settings, including neonatal nurseries.

B) INCORRECT:

Routine prophylactic antibiotics for staff are not effective in preventing hospital-acquired infections and are not supported by evidence. This approach does not address infection control lapses like inadequate hand hygiene. Additionally, it risks antibiotic resistance and disrupts normal flora, complicating infection control.

C) INCORRECT:

Increasing the nurse-to-patient ratio may reduce workload but does not directly address infection transmission via direct contact, which is likely the primary vector in this scenario. Hand hygiene practices are more critical in preventing pathogen spread in neonatal settings.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultraviolet disinfection lamps inactivate microorganisms on surfaces but are limited by incomplete coverage and safety concerns. In this scenario, thorough manual surface disinfection is already in place, and UV lamps do not address direct contact transmission routes, such as those involving healthcare workers' hands.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents with fatigue, low-grade fevers, and a productive cough occasionally streaked with blood for two months. He recently arrived from a region with high tuberculosis prevalence. Physical examination reveals crackles in the left upper lung field (see report).

Oxygen saturation
97% on room air

Chest X-ray: Cavitary lesion in the left apex
Which of the following isolation measures is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Contact precautions with gowns and gloves
Negative-pressure room with N95 respirators for staff

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contact precautions with gowns and gloves prevent transmission of pathogens spread by direct contact, such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Tuberculosis is transmitted via airborne droplet nuclei, requiring airborne precautions with negative-pressure rooms and N95 respirators, not contact precautions.

B) INCORRECT:

Standard precautions, including hand hygiene and personal protective equipment, prevent contact with blood and bodily fluids. However, pulmonary tuberculosis requires airborne precautions due to its transmission via droplet nuclei. The patient's symptoms and cavitary lesion suggest tuberculosis, necessitating negative-pressure rooms and N95 masks, which standard precautions do not provide.

C) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions with surgical masks are effective for pathogens transmitted by large droplets (>5 μm), such as influenza. However, Mycobacterium tuberculosis spreads via smaller droplet nuclei (<5 μm) that remain airborne. This requires N95 respirators and negative-pressure rooms, which droplet precautions do not provide.

D) CORRECT:

Pulmonary tuberculosis is transmitted via airborne droplet nuclei, which can remain suspended in the air and spread over long distances. Negative-pressure rooms ensure air flows into the room, preventing contamination of adjacent areas. N95 respirators filter out these infectious particles, protecting healthcare staff. The cavitary lesion in the lung apex increases aerosol generation during coughing, necessitating strict airborne precautions to prevent transmission and protect healthcare workers and other patients.

Key learning point: Airborne precautions are required for patients suspected of having pulmonary tuberculosis, as it is spread through tiny droplets in the air.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with a 3-week history of cough producing streaks of blood, night sweats, mild fever, and a 5-kg unintentional weight loss. He has a 15-year history of smoking and episodes of heavy alcohol use. He appears fatigued. Bilateral breath sounds are diminished at the apices (see report).


Heart rate
92/min


Blood pressure
115/75 mm Hg


Temperature
37.8 °C


Chest X-ray: Patchy consolidation in the right upper lobe
Laboratory analysis is pending. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Empiric intravenous antibiotics for typical pneumonia
CT scan of the chest before isolation measures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Outpatient sputum testing is inappropriate given the patient's significant symptoms and high suspicion of tuberculosis. Delaying testing risks transmission and delays diagnosis and treatment. Immediate sputum testing is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate management, especially with signs of significant pulmonary pathology.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including prolonged cough, hemoptysis, night sweats, and weight loss, along with the chest x-ray showing upper lobe consolidation, strongly suggest active pulmonary tuberculosis. Implementing airborne precautions with negative-pressure isolation is crucial to prevent nosocomial transmission, as tuberculosis spreads via airborne droplet nuclei. Negative-pressure rooms help contain infectious aerosols, protecting healthcare workers and other patients while diagnostic tests, such as acid-fast bacilli stains and cultures, are conducted.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected tuberculosis with upper lobe consolidation, immediate isolation in a negative pressure room is crucial to prevent airborne transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

While chest x-ray findings of consolidation might suggest bacterial pneumonia, the patient's chronic symptoms, including hemoptysis, night sweats, and weight loss, indicate a chronic infectious process like tuberculosis. Typical bacterial pneumonia usually presents acutely and involves lower lobes. Empiric IV antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia are not appropriate here, as they may not cover tuberculosis and could delay necessary diagnostic testing.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan provides detailed imaging but is secondary in suspected active pulmonary tuberculosis. The priority is to implement infection control measures to prevent transmission. Delaying isolation for imaging can risk exposing healthcare workers and patients. While CT may later help assess complications, immediate isolation is essential when clinical suspicion is high.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old woman is admitted with confusion and found to have a large post-void residual volume. A urinary catheter is placed. Over the next three days, her mental status improves, and she resumes adequate spontaneous voiding. She remains hemodynamically stable, with no ongoing indication for measuring precise output, but the catheter is left in place.
Which of the following measures is most effective at reducing her risk for catheter-associated urinary tract infection?

choices.text: Replace the indwelling catheter every 48 hours
Remove the catheter as soon as it is no longer indicated
Irrigate the catheter with normal saline every 8 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Frequent catheter replacement does not reduce CAUTI risk and disrupts the sterile drainage system, increasing infection risk. Each replacement introduces new bacteria and does not eliminate established biofilms. Minimizing catheter dwell time is more effective in reducing infection risk than routine replacement.

B) INCORRECT:

Daily prophylactic antibiotics are not recommended for asymptomatic catheterized patients, as they do not reduce CAUTI incidence and can lead to antibiotic resistance and secondary infections, such as Clostridium difficile colitis. The biofilm formation on catheters is not effectively prevented by systemic antibiotics, and the risks of resistance and adverse effects outweigh any potential benefits.

C) CORRECT:

Indwelling urinary catheters significantly increase the risk of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) due to biofilm formation and bacterial colonization, which escalate with prolonged catheterization. Prompt removal of the catheter when it is no longer necessary, such as after the patient resumes adequate spontaneous voiding, is the most effective measure to prevent CAUTIs. This approach reduces the duration of bacterial exposure to the bladder, aligning with infection control guidelines that emphasize minimizing unnecessary catheter use.

Key learning point: To prevent catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) in elderly patients, it is crucial to review the need for urinary catheters daily and remove them as soon as they are no longer necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine irrigation with normal saline does not reduce CAUTI risk and may increase infection risk by disrupting the closed drainage system. Irrigation is typically reserved for catheter obstruction, not infection prevention. Effective catheter management focuses on aseptic handling, maintaining a closed system, and timely removal.

questions.text: Five days after being admitted to hospital for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia, a 76-year-old man develops watery diarrhea and cramping lower abdominal pain. Today, he has had three episodes of foul-smelling, nonbloody diarrhea without nausea or vomiting. His current medications are cefotaxime and clarithromycin. His temperature is 37.5°C, pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. On abdominal examination, there is mild tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. White blood cell count is 13.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5). Stool analysis is pending. In addition to isolating the patient and wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry, which one of the following infection control measures is most appropriate to prevent transmission of the organism responsible for his gastrointestinal symptoms?

choices.text: Wash hands with soap and water.
No further infection control measures are required.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Adequate hand hygiene, which is a standard precaution, should always be performed by health care providers (HCPs) for infection control before and after contact with a patient, regardless of whether or not the patient has an infection. In most instances, the use of alcohol-based hand rubs (ABHRs) alone is a quicker and superior method of hand hygiene than washing hands with soap and water. However, hand hygiene with soap and water rather than an ABHR is required if the HCP's hands are visibly soiled or when caring for patients with acute infectious diarrhea or infections due to spore-forming organisms such as C. difficile, because ABHRs are ineffective against spores. Wearing gloves and a gown is an important adjunct in preventing contamination with spores but is not a substitute for hand hygiene. HCPs should wash hands with soap and water before putting on gloves and gowns as well as after removing them.

When caring for patients with contact-transmitted diseases such as C. difficile infection, in addition to standard precautions, HCPs should follow contact precautions (e.g., isolating patients, wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry).

Key learning point: Hand washing with soap and water is essential to prevent Clostridioides difficile transmission because alcohol-based hand rubs are ineffective against its spores.

B) INCORRECT:

Health care providers wear an N95 respirator as part of airborne precautions when caring for patients with diseases spread by person-to-person airborne transmission (e.g., tuberculosis, measles, varicella). Prevention of C. difficile transmission does not require airborne precautions.

Legionnaire disease (LD), which causes acute pneumonia and GI symptoms (e.g., watery diarrhea, abdominal pain), can spread in hospitals via airborne transmission as a result of aerosol generation from a contaminated water source (e.g., through an airconditioning unit or shower). However, patients with LD usually develop pneumonia and GI symptoms simultaneously, unlike this patient who developed GI symptoms 5 days after being admitted for pneumonia. Moreover, transmission-based precautions (e.g., airborne precautions) are not indicated when caring for patients with LD because person-to-person transmission of LD is extremely rare.

C) INCORRECT:

Alcohol-based foam or gel hand rubs are quick to use and more effective against most organisms than other hand hygiene methods, but they are ineffective against spore-forming organisms such as C. difficile.

D) INCORRECT:

Health care providers should always follow standard precautions for infection control regardless of whether or not the patient has an infection. Standard precautions are not fulfilled by only isolating the patient and wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry.

E) INCORRECT:

When caring for patients, health care providers should wear a surgical mask as part of standard precautions when there is a risk of exposure to body fluids or other potentially infectious material (e.g., when performing a procedure that can generate splashes or sprays) and as a part of droplet precautions (e.g., when within 3–6 feet of a patient with a droplet-transmitted infection). Prevention of C. difficile transmission does not require droplet precautions; a different element of standard precautions prevents transmission.
questions.hint: Clostridioides difficile infection, which typically occurs after initiating broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy, is the cause of this patient's gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms (i.e., foul-smelling watery diarrhea, abdominal pain).

questions.text: You are a healthy 26-year-old clinician who sustains a needlestick injury from an exposed catheter needle while placing a central venous catheter in a critically ill patient with known HIV/AIDS who is not currently taking antiretroviral therapy. You have no other recent exposures to HIV. You previously received hepatitis B (HBV) vaccination but did not have post-vaccination testing to confirm seroconversion. You were born in Canada and have no other risk factors for HBV infection. Which one of the following combinations of diagnostic tests should you undergo immediately?

choices.text: HIV antibody and HIV viral load.
HIV antibody, HIV viral load, and hepatitis B surface antibody.
HIV antibody, HIV viral load, and hepatitis C antibody.
HIV antibody, hepatitis B surface antibody, and hepatitis C antibody.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure. Testing for hepatitis B virus (HBV) surface antibody is also part of the postexposure evaluation to determine immunity to HBV infection.

C) INCORRECT:

An HIV antibody test should be performed immediately after a needlestick exposure to HIV. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection. HIV viral load testing should not be part of the initial laboratory evaluation because a negative result will not exclude the possibility that transmission occurred during this exposure. Testing for hepatitis C virus antibody is also part of the postexposure evaluation to determine possible infection with this virus before the needlestick exposure.

D) CORRECT:

When an asymptomatic individual has a needlestick exposure to HIV, an HIV antibody test should be performed right away. A positive result indicates prior HIV infection, and the individual should be referred for evaluation and treatment of HIV infection but not for postexposure prophylaxis (PEP).

Postexposure evaluation should also include tests for hepatitis B virus (HBV) surface antibody and hepatitis C virus (HCV) antibody. A positive test for HCV antibody indicates possible infection with this virus before the needlestick exposure. A positive test for HBV surface antibody indicates that the exposed individual is immune to HBV infection (either from prior vaccination or from seroconversion after prior infection). If HBV surface antibody is negative, another HBV vaccination series should be initiated with PEP.

Baseline complete blood count, liver function tests, and creatinine levels should also be obtained. If abnormal, these values will influence the decision about which combination of antiretrovirals to use as PEP — and will also establish a baseline to monitor for antiretroviral toxicities after PEP initiation.

Key learning point: A person who is exposed to HIV infection from a needlestick injury should undergo an initial postexposure evaluation that includes assessments for prior chronic viral infections (HIV, hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus).

questions.text: Two hours after admission to the intensive care unit, you are caring for a 56-year-old man with necrotizing pancreatitis who develops profound hypotension. His blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, and vasopressors are initiated. A central venous access line is placed. Which one of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of complications from central venous catheter placement?

choices.text: Replacement of the central venous line every 7-10 days.
Initiation of periprocedural systemic antibiotic prophylaxis.
Preparation of the patient's skin with chlorhexidine and alcohol.
Placement of the central venous line in the femoral vein.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Routine replacement of CVL every 7–10 days is not recommended because it does not reduce the risk of CLABSI and unnecessarily exposes the patient to additional procedures. Central lines should be inserted and accessed only when absolutely necessary and then removed as soon as possible. Hospitalized patients with CVLs should be assessed daily to determine whether or not the line can be removed.

B) INCORRECT:

Periprocedural systemic antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely performed during CVL insertion to reduce catheter colonization or CLABSI. Flushing of the line with antibiotics is generally only considered in patients who require long-term central venous access or who are immune suppressed.

C) CORRECT:

Proper hand hygiene and preparing the patient's skin with chlorhexidine and alcohol is the most effective strategy in decreasing the risk of infection (e.g., CLABSI) from CVL placement. Chlorhexidine has proven superior to iodine-based compounds for antisepsis.

Key learning point: Skin preparation with chlorhexidine and alcohol before central venous catheter insertion is the most effective way to reduce the risk of central-line associated bloodstream infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is not routinely performed after central venous line placement to reduce the risk of catheter-related complications. Flushing of the line with heparin should only be considered in patients who require long-term central venous access.

E) INCORRECT:

Placing the CVL in the femoral vein would not reduce complications, as femoral lines carry an increased risk of CLABSI due to their location. The preferred sites for CVL insertion are the subclavian and internal jugular veins. While the subclavian site minimizes the risk of infection, it is associated with a higher rate of iatrogenic pneumothorax. The internal jugular site, on the other hand, is associated with a greater risk of infection but a lower risk of pneumothorax.
questions.hint: Precautions must be taken when placing central venous catheters to prevent central-line associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI).

questions.text: You are seeing an 82-year-old man with alcohol use disorder who is brought to the emergency department from his assisted living facility due to a 1-week history of fever and productive cough with thick, mucoid, blood-tinged sputum. His temperature is 38.5°C and respirations are 20/min. On examination, there are coarse inspiratory crackles over the right lung field. Sputum cultures reveal gram-negative, encapsulated bacilli resistant to amoxicillin, ceftriaxone, and aztreonam. Which one of the following infection control measures is most appropriate to prevent transmission of this organism to other patients in the hospital?

choices.text: Transfer patient to a positive pressure room.
Isolate patient to a single-occupancy room.
Transfer patient to a negative pressure room.
Require all staff and visitors to wear droplet masks.
Require autoclave sterilization of all medical instruments.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Positive pressure rooms can be used for immunocompromised patients. They have a ventilation system that creates positive pressure in the room, allowing air to flow out of and preventing air from being drawn into the room. This is not indicated in this patient as he is not immunocompromised, and it would not help reduce transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.

B) CORRECT:

Multidrug-resistant strains of bacteria, such as ESBL-producing strains, are a greater public health hazard than infections with organisms of a normal resistance spectrum, and thus need stricter infection control measures. In addition to the standard contact precautions and strict hand hygiene, patients should be isolated in single-occupancy rooms.

Key learning point: Patients with infections caused by multidrug-resistant organisms should be placed in single-occupancy rooms with strict contact precautions and hand hygiene to prevent transmission to others.

C) INCORRECT:

Negative pressure rooms are used for highly contagious airborne diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, measles, varicella, smallpox). They have a ventilation system that creates negative pressure in the room, allowing air to flow into and preventing air from flowing out of the room. Moving the patient to a negative pressure room is not necessary to prevent transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.

D) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions are used for highly contagious diseases that are transmitted through particles of respiratory secretions. These include Neisseria meningitidis, influenza, Bordetella pertussis, and others. ESBL-producing bacteria are not transmitted through droplets and therefore droplet precautions are not indicated in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Autoclave sterilization of all medical instruments is used in prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, as well as in spore-forming bacteria or fungi. It is not necessary to prevent transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.
questions.hint: Fever, productive cough, and localized crackles are suggestive of pneumonia. The patient's currant jelly sputum, residency in an assisted living facility, alcohol use disorder, and findings of gram-negative, encapsulated bacilli make healthcare-associated Klebsiella pneumonia a likely diagnosis. Sputum cultures show multi-drug resistance, raising suspicion for an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing (ESBL) strain of this bacteria.

questions.text: You are caring for a 65-year-old woman who was admitted to the intensive care unit three days ago following major trauma from a motor vehicle accident. She was intubated and mechanically ventilated on admission due to unconsciousness. Over the past 12 hours, her end-expiratory airway pressure was increased to maintain adequate oxygenation. She now develops respiratory distress. Her current temperature is 39.1°C, pulse is 114/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. A chest x-ray shows new alveolar infiltrates and air bronchograms in the right lower lobe. Which one of the following measures is most likely to have prevented her current condition?

choices.text: Starting proton pump inhibitor therapy early.
Avoiding overinflation of the endotracheal tube cuff.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sedatives are used in mechanically ventilated patients to relieve discomfort and anxiety and, if a spontaneous ventilatory mode is unavailable, to prevent complications arising from patient-ventilator asynchrony. However, excessive sedation impairs the patient's airway protective reflexes and allows oropharyngeal secretions or gastric reflux to pass beyond the glottis. In intubated patients, these collections can pool in the subglottic region and drain around the endotracheal tube cuff, as microaspirates, into the lower respiratory tract. Using sedation assessment tools and daily titration of the patient's depth of sedation to the minimum necessary level (sedation vacation) can prevent the subglottic pooling of secretions and subsequent VAP. Sedation vacations also prevent VAP by facilitating spontaneous breathing trials and early ventilator weaning.

VAP can also be prevented by measures that decrease oropharyngeal or gastrointestinal bacterial colonization (e.g., oral chlorhexidine rinses, avoiding unnecessary acid suppression therapy), decrease subglottic pooling (e.g., oropharyngeal and subglottic suctioning, semirecumbent positioning of the patient), and decrease the risk of microaspiration (e.g., minimizing patient transport, avoiding frequent ventilator circuit changes for the same patient).

Key learning point: Minimizing sedation in mechanically ventilated patients reduces the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia by preserving airway protective reflexes and facilitating earlier weaning from the ventilator.

B) INCORRECT:

Acid suppression (e.g., proton pump inhibitor) therapy is used for stress ulcer prophylaxis in critically ill patients with certain risk factors (e.g., traumatic brain injury, prolonged mechanical ventilation and/ or stay in intensive care unit). However, acid suppression also promotes bacterial colonization of the gastrointestinal tract, which increases rather than decreases the risk of VAP.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine oropharyngeal and subglottic suctioning prevents the pooling of secretions above the endotracheal tube cuff. Avoiding routine oropharyngeal suctioning would increase rather than decrease the risk of VAP.

D) INCORRECT:

Biofilms of bacteria can adhere to the ventilator circuit and lead to VAP. Therefore, a change in the ventilator circuit is recommended if it is visibly soiled, malfunctioning, or if a new patient is ventilated. However, frequent changes of the ventilator circuit for the same patient increase rather than decrease the risk of VAP because manipulation of the ventilator circuit increases the risk of microaspiration of subglottic secretions.

E) INCORRECT:

Adequate inflation of the endotracheal tube cuff (to a pressure of 20–30 mm H2O) is required to minimize the risk of VAP. While avoiding overinflation of the endotracheal tube cuff prevents airway injury (e.g., ischemia, ulceration, and necrosis of the tracheal wall), it does not prevent VAP.
questions.hint: Tachycardia, tachypnea, fever, and new infiltrates on chest x-ray after being intubated for more than 48 hours indicate ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is most often caused by microaspiration of bacterial flora from the oral cavity or stomach.

questions.text: You are seeing a 46-year-old man who is incarcerated and presents to the county jail urgent care clinic with a 1-month history of productive cough, malaise, right-sided chest pain, shortness of breath, and a 6-kg weight loss. He is diagnosed with tuberculosis and admitted to hospital. While on the ward, a student enters his room without using infection prevention and control measures. Afterward, the nurse informs the student about the required infection prevention precautions. Which one of the following isolation precautions is most appropriate to prevent transmission of the causal organism to others?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contact precautions are used to prevent the transmission of pathogens that spread via direct contact or fomites (e.g., norovirus). These measures include the use of gloves and gowns but not necessarily the use of masks. Because tuberculosis spreads through small particles that enter the respiratory system with the air, contact precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions are used to prevent the transmission of pathogens that spread via droplets > 5 μm in size (e.g., influenza) . These measures include the use of surgical masks within a distance of 1–2 meters from the patient. Because tuberculosis is transmitted through even smaller particles that can pass through surgical masks, droplet precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with active tuberculosis (TB) disperse bacilli-containing droplet nuclei (aerosols) while coughing or sneezing, warranting airborne precautions in addition to standard precautions. Patients with suspected or confirmed active TB must be placed in airborne infection isolation rooms (AIIRs) because droplet nuclei can remain suspended in the air and travel long distances. The negative air pressure in AIIRs prevents contaminated air from escaping. Furthermore, patients with active TB must wear surgical face masks in an ambulatory care setting or while being transported to another facility. Health care personnel should wear an N95 respirator (or a higher-level respirator) before entering the AIIR.

Other infections requiring airborne precautions include measles, varicella, smallpox, and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) infections (e.g., COVID-19).

Key learning point: Active tuberculosis requires airborne precautions, including use of an N95 respirator and a negative pressure room, to prevent transmission of aerosolized Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Standard precautions are used for the care of all patients, whether or not an infection is probable. These measures include respiratory hygiene, but not necessarily wearing a mask. Because tuberculosis spreads through small particles that enter the respiratory system with the air, standard precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.
questions.hint: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is transmitted via infectious particles measuring 1 to 5 μm.

questions.text: Five days after a right hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 62-year-old man is seeing you with fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and urinary frequency. The surgery was uncomplicated, and an indwelling urinary catheter was placed during the procedure. His temperature is 39.4°C, pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 118/83 mm Hg. He has tenderness to palpation at the costovertebral angle. The urine in the catheter bag appears cloudy. Which one of the following measures is most likely to have prevented his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most effective measures for the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (UTIs) are avoidance of unnecessary catheterization, sterile technique during catheter placement, and early removal of urinary catheters when they are no longer indicated; patients undergoing surgery not involving the urinary tract should have their catheters removed as soon as possible (preferably within 24 hours postoperatively).

Key learning point: Early removal of urinary catheters when no longer needed is the most effective way to prevent catheter-associated urinary tract infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Periurethral care with soap and water is considered adequate maintenance care for an indwelling catheter. However, it has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Likewise, the use of antiseptics for cleaning the meatal area, either before or after catheter placement, has not been shown to prevent infections and may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens.

C) INCORRECT:

Antimicrobial prophylaxis has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Furthermore, excessive use of prophylactic antibiotics should be avoided, because it may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens. Intravenous antimicrobial prophylaxis administered shortly before surgery, on the other hand, is an effective intervention for the prevention of surgical site infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Although it has been shown that urinary antiseptics such as methenamine can have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections, the evidence is limited, and the use of urinary antiseptics is not generally recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Although there may be a temporary reduction in the number of bacteria found in the urine following the changing of a catheter, daily catheter replacement has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Therefore, indwelling catheters should not be replaced routinely as long as the urinary flow appears adequate.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, abdominal pain, nausea, urinary frequency, flank pain, and cloudy urine suggest pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old health care worker presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of low-grade fever, malaise, and intermittent cough. She works in a busy urban emergency department and reports frequent exposure to patients with respiratory complaints. Chest x-ray shows left-sided hilar lymphadenopathy and left-sided upper lobe consolidation. Sputum samples have been collected for acid-fast bacilli testing. She is placed in an isolation room. What is the most appropriate personal protective equipment for the emergency physician entering her room?

choices.text: Surgical mask, nonsterile gloves, gown, and face shield
N95 respirator, nonsterile gloves, and gown
N95 respirator, sterile gloves, and sterile gown

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While N95 respirator protection is warranted for suspected tuberculosis, standard precautions also require gloves and gown for any patient contact to protect against body fluid exposure during clinical care.

B) INCORRECT:

A surgical mask provides inadequate protection against airborne pathogens. The clinical presentation suggests possible tuberculosis, which requires airborne precautions with respirator protection due to small particle transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

Face shields protect against splashes, but surgical masks are insufficient for airborne precautions. Tuberculosis transmission occurs through small aerosolized particles that require respirator-level protection, not surgical mask filtration.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Suspected tuberculosis requires airborne precautions with fitted respirator protection. Standard precautions mandate nonsterile gloves and gown for patient contact. The upper lobe infiltrate in a health care worker with occupational exposure to respiratory illness warrants airborne isolation and standard precautions pending test results.

E) INCORRECT:

Sterile equipment is unnecessary for routine patient care and tuberculosis isolation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the ED with fever, cough, and hypoxemia, and is placed in airborne and contact isolation. An emergency physician prepares to enter the patient’s room. Hand hygiene has already been performed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in donning personal protective equipment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Putting on gloves is the last step in donning PPE.

B) CORRECT:

Correct — After hand hygiene, the gown is donned first to protect clothing and skin. Respirator and eye protection follow, with gloves applied last.

C) INCORRECT:

Eye protection is the penultimate step in donning PPE. Performing this step now is out of sequence.

D) INCORRECT:

Respiratory protection is crucial for airborne precautions, but it is preceded by another step.

E) INCORRECT:

Hand hygiene is performed before donning PPE and after doffing, but repeating it at this stage is not part of the standard sequence.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after cutting his hand on broken glass. The wound is 4 cm long with visible debris. Vital signs are normal. Irrigation and closure are planned. Which of the following is the most appropriate combination of personal protective equipment for this intervention?

choices.text: Gloves, face shield, mask, and cap

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This combination of PPE does not guard against fluid splash to the eyes or body, which is required for splash-prone procedures such as wound irrigation.

B) INCORRECT:

This combination of PPE leaves the body exposed to bodily fluids.

C) INCORRECT:

This combination of PPE provides body and respiratory protection but omits eye protection. Wound irrigation creates splash risk, making eye protection mandatory.

D) CORRECT:

Correct — Gloves are required for all patient contact, while a mask and eye protection protect the face from splash, and a gown protects clothing and skin. This combination represents the appropriate application of universal precautions for a procedure with expected fluid exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

A face shield provides eye and some facial protection, but this combination lacks body and respiratory protection, which are required for splash-prone procedures.

questions.text: An emergency department nurse sustains a deep hollow-bore needlestick injury while drawing blood from an unconscious patient brought in by EMS. The patient was found unresponsive in a park with no identification, and EMS reports finding drug paraphernalia nearby. The patient remains unresponsive to verbal stimuli. The nurse immediately washed the wound with soap and water and allowed it to bleed under running water. She completed her hepatitis B vaccination series 18 months ago and adequate anti-HBs titers were documented 6 months ago. Baseline laboratory studies for the nurse have been obtained, and source testing has been sent but will not be available for several hours. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Await source patient results to guide management
Schedule follow-up testing for the nurse
Complete an occupational health incident report

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Source testing is important, but it should not delay the immediate initiation of postexposure prophylaxis after a high-risk exposure.

B) CORRECT:

Correct — This is a high-risk percutaneous exposure from a hollow-bore needle with no history available for the patient, and results will be delayed. HIV postexposure prophylaxis should be initiated promptly, as efficacy decreases with time. Hepatitis B prophylaxis is unnecessary because protective immunity is documented.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B immune globulin is indicated for exposures in providers without immunity or with inadequate antibody titers. This nurse has documented protective levels, so HBIG is not required.

D) INCORRECT:

Follow-up serologic testing is part of occupational exposure management, but it is not the immediate next step.

E) INCORRECT:

Documentation with occupational health is required, but administrative steps should not precede initiation of clinical management.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with confusion and poor oral intake. The patient was discharged from the hospital 1 week ago following a 3-week stay for complications from abdominal surgery, including wound infection treated with vancomycin and meropenem. Vital signs are BP, 88/55; P, 105; R, 24; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F); oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. The patient appears dehydrated with dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor. Which infection control measure should be implemented immediately?

choices.text: Protective environment with positive pressure room
Contact precautions with gloves and gowns
Standard precautions with routine hand hygiene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions are used for respiratory infections transmitted by large droplets, such as influenza or pertussis. This patient's presentation suggests systemic infection with dehydration rather than a respiratory droplet-transmitted infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Protective environment precautions are used for severely immunocompromised patients, particularly allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients, to protect them from environmental pathogens. This patient requires isolation to prevent transmission to others, not protection from the environment.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Contact precautions are appropriate for patients with risk factors for multidrug-resistant organism (MDRO) colonization. The combination of a prolonged hospital stay, recent treatment with vancomycin and meropenem, and a history of wound infection is a high risk for MDRO colonization. Contact precautions require gloves and gowns for all health care providers to prevent transmission through direct contact with body fluids or contaminated surfaces.

D) INCORRECT:

Standard precautions alone are insufficient for this patient. The combination of prolonged hospitalization, recent broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy, and surgical site infection is a significant risk for multidrug-resistant organism colonization, requiring additional precautions.

E) INCORRECT:

Airborne precautions are used for infections transmitted by small airborne particles such as tuberculosis or varicella. This patient's clinical presentation does not suggest an airborne infection requiring N95 respirators.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nurse presents to the emergency department after a needlestick injury in the operating room involving a patient with a recent positive hepatitis C RNA test. The nurse's initial hepatitis C antibody test is negative. When should she be counseled to have repeat hepatitis C RNA testing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C RNA testing at 1–2 weeks is too early to be diagnostic.

B) INCORRECT:

Testing at 4–6 months is the recommended timeframe for subsequent anti-HCV antibody testing, rather than hepatitis C RNA testing, which is performed earlier to detect acute infection before antibodies develop.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Hepatitis C RNA testing at 3–6 weeks allows for early detection of acute hepatitis C infection as viral RNA becomes detectable earlier than antibodies.

D) INCORRECT:

Testing at 9–12 months is unnecessarily delayed as both hepatitis C RNA and anti-HCV antibodies are detectable much earlier if infection occurred, missing the opportunity for timely diagnosis and treatment of acute hepatitis C.

E) INCORRECT:

Follow-up testing is essential after hepatitis C exposure to assess for infection as there is no available postexposure prophylaxis. Furthermore, early detection enables prompt treatment if an acute infection develops.

questions.text: Ten days after the placement of a tunneled central venous catheter in the subclavian vein, a hospitalized 68-year-old woman develops fever and hypotension. Samples for blood culture are drawn simultaneously from the central line and a peripheral vein. Blood cultures from the central line grow nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacilli. Three hours later, blood cultures from the peripheral venipuncture grow the same bacteria. Which of the following is the most effective measure to reduce the incidence of this patient's current infection?

choices.text: Administration of ceftazidime through the introducer needle before passing the guide wire.
Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure in intensive care units.
Application of mupirocin ointment to the anterior nares of critically ill patients.
Placement of central venous catheters in the femoral rather than subclavian vein.
Implementation of real-time feedback loops for hand hygiene compliance.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceftazidime is an antibiotic that is effective against P. aeruginosa, and antibiotic lock therapy (e.g., with ceftazidime-heparin solutions) can be used selectively for the secondary prevention of CLABSI. However, antibiotics are ineffective in the primary prevention of CLABSI and do not have a role before or during CVC insertion (e.g., through the introducer needle). Antibiotics should only be used if indicated and, in such cases, the principle of antibiotic stewardship should be followed.

B) INCORRECT:

Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure is an example of an airborne precaution, which is effective in preventing in-hospital airborne transmission of diseases such as tuberculosis, measles, or varicella. P. aeruginosa is spread via contact transmission; standard precautions and contact precautions are effective in preventing nosocomial P. aeruginosa infections but airborne precautions are not. Moreover, in intensive care units, especially ones caring for immunosuppressed patients, a protective environment with a positive rather than negative ambient air pressure is usually maintained (neutropenic precautions).

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus, which causes nosocomial infections including CLABSI, often colonizes the anterior nares, and nasal application of mupirocin ointment is recommended for critically ill patients as part of the universal decolonization protocol to prevent methicillin-resistant S. aureus infection. However, S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus whereas this patient has a P. aeruginosa infection. P. aeruginosa rarely colonizes the upper airways (e.g., in patients with cystic fibrosis) and mupirocin is typically ineffective against Pseudomonas spp.

D) INCORRECT:

When compared with the subclavian vein, placement of CVCs in the femoral vein has a lower risk of certain insertion-related complications (e.g., pneumothorax, hematomas, vein stenosis) but a higher risk of CLABSI. Moreover, femoral CVCs are more likely to result in CLABSIs with gram-negative bacilli and Candida because the groin area has high levels of colonization by these microbes (due to factors such as moisture in intertriginous areas and proximity to the anogenital region) and is harder to keep clean. Femoral CVCs should be avoided.

E) CORRECT:

The most common mechanism for CLABSI is microbial spread (via surface motility and/or biofilm formation) to the CVC exit site from the patient's skin and/or the CVC hub. The hands of health care providers (HCPs) are often colonized by pathogens, resulting in HCPs cross-contaminating patients, other HCPs, and inanimate objects (leading to contact transmission), thereby facilitating nosocomial infections. Strict adherence to hand hygiene measures is necessary to prevent nosocomial infections such as CLABSI. Despite high numbers of hand hygiene stations and visual reminders at hospitals, the level of hand hygiene compliance among HCPs remains low because of lapses (due to work overload), poor situational awareness, and/or intolerance or aversion to certain disinfectants. An effective measure to increase compliance is a real-time feedback loop, in which hand hygiene observers or electronic hand hygiene systems monitor compliance and provide immediate feedback (e.g., verbal feedback on improper technique, data visualization of each hospital floor's hand hygiene process measures). Additional steps to increase hand hygiene compliance include staff training and providing alcohol-based foam rubs (which are quicker to use, more effective, and no more irritating to the skin than soap and water) at hand hygiene stations.

CLABSI bundles (a collection of measures to prevent CLABSI) include proper site identification and technique for CVC insertion (e.g., avoiding the femoral region whenever possible), standardized checklists, and aseptic precautions (e.g., sterile glove use, disinfection with chlorhexidine) for CVC insertion as well as CVC site care, CVC removal as soon as possible, and champions-led rounding. These measures are important adjuncts but not substitutes for hand hygiene.

Key learning point: Strict hand hygiene with real-time compliance feedback is the most effective strategy to prevent central-line-associated bloodstream infections.

questions.hint: The onset of fever and hemodynamic instability ≥ 48 hours after the insertion of a central venous catheter (CVC) and the growth of the same organism on blood cultures from the CVC and a peripheral vein with a differential time to positivity ≥ 120 minutes indicate a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacillus that causes CLABSI.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever, myalgias, headache, and a nonproductive cough. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. He appears fatigued. Physical examination shows diffuse muscle tenderness. Lung auscultation is clear. A rapid antigen test for influenza is pending. While awaiting results, which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate to implement?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contact precautions are used for pathogens spread by direct or indirect contact, such as Clostridioides difficile or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. This typically involves wearing a gown and gloves. While influenza can be transmitted via contact with contaminated surfaces (fomites), its primary mode of transmission is another route. Therefore, contact precautions alone are inadequate to prevent the spread of influenza.

B) INCORRECT:

Airborne precautions are required for pathogens transmitted by small droplet nuclei (< 5 micrometers) that can remain suspended in the air for extended periods, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, measles, or varicella. This requires a negative-pressure isolation room and an N95 respirator. Influenza is transmitted by larger droplets that do not remain airborne over long distances, making this level of precaution unnecessary for routine patient care.

C) INCORRECT:

A Protective environment, which involves a positive-pressure room with high-efficiency particulate air filtration, is designed to protect severely immunocompromised patients (e.g., stem cell transplant recipients) from acquiring infections from their surroundings. This is a form of reverse isolation. It is not appropriate for this patient, who is the source of a potential infection and requires measures to prevent spread to others.

D) INCORRECT:

Standard precautions, which include hand hygiene and the use of personal protective equipment based on anticipated exposure, are the minimum infection prevention practices applied to all patients. However, they are insufficient for pathogens such as influenza that are transmitted by specific routes requiring additional transmission-based precautions. Relying on standard precautions alone would pose a significant risk of transmission to other patients and health care workers.

E) CORRECT:

The influenza virus is primarily transmitted via large respiratory droplets generated when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. These droplets travel short distances (typically ≤ 6 feet). Therefore, droplet precautions are indicated to prevent nosocomial transmission. These precautions include placing the patient in a private room (or cohorting with another patient with influenza) and requiring health care personnel to wear a surgical mask when entering the room, in addition to standard precautions. These measures should be implemented empirically while awaiting confirmatory test results.
questions.hint: Consider the primary mode of transmission for the influenza virus, which is strongly suggested by this patient's abrupt onset of fever, myalgias, and cough.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old college freshman is brought to the Emergency Department by roommates due to fever, severe headache, and generalized malaise for the past 12 hours. He has neck stiffness and small, irregular petechial lesions over his trunk. He is lethargic but responds to stimuli, without focal neurologic deficits. A lumbar puncture is performed, and preliminary Gram stain suggests Gram-negative diplococci. Respiratory, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid cultures are pending. It is believed he may have meningococcal meningitis.

Temperature
39.5°C

Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Contact precautions requiring gown and gloves for all contact
Full barrier precautions with N95 respirator, face shield, gloves, and gown
Droplet precautions with surgical masks for staff in close contact
Airborne isolation using an N95 respirator and negative-pressure room

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contact precautions prevent transmission via direct contact or contaminated surfaces, suitable for pathogens like Clostridium difficile. Neisseria meningitidis spreads through respiratory droplets, not direct contact, so droplet precautions are necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Full barrier precautions are for airborne pathogens like varicella-zoster virus. Neisseria meningitidis spreads via respiratory droplets, requiring droplet precautions with surgical masks, not full barrier precautions.

C) CORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis, responsible for meningococcal meningitis, spreads via respiratory droplets. These droplets are expelled during coughing or sneezing and require droplet precautions to prevent transmission. Healthcare workers should wear surgical masks when within 3 feet of the patient to intercept these droplets. The patient's symptoms, including fever, neck stiffness, and petechial rash, along with Gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain, support the diagnosis. Droplet precautions are appropriate to manage this infection and prevent nosocomial spread.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected or confirmed meningococcal meningitis, droplet precautions are necessary to prevent transmission of Neisseria meningitidis, which is spread through respiratory droplets.

D) INCORRECT:

Airborne isolation is for pathogens transmitted as tiny particles that remain suspended in the air, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Neisseria meningitidis spreads through larger respiratory droplets, not airborne particles, so droplet precautions, not airborne isolation, are appropriate.
